loans.name: Xuan's Group

texts.en:
Xuan T. T. H. is 33 years old. She lives in Cau Ca village, Co Loa, Dong Anh, Ha Noi with her husband and two sons. Both of her sons are going to school. She cooks for the workers of the company near her house. Besides that, she breeds pigs and poultry. She has a monthly income of about 2,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND), which is about $105 US. 

Since joining the SEDA microfinance program in 2008, she has been a dynamic, energetic and respected leader of an eight-member group.  But, In her group only three members borrow money. Other members are continuing to repay loans. This cycle, Ms Xuan needs 5,450,000 VND to invest in her livestock.

About two other members in her group:

Tho T. N. is 39 years old. She is a worker. She wants to buy pigs to breed. So, she wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy some pigs.
Tan T. P. is 49 years old. She has a store at home. She wants to borrow 654,000 VND to invest in her store.

loans.use: For livestock

loans.name: Sary

texts.en: Mrs. Sary S. is 40 years old and a villager who lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Ly Ouk, sells ice cream and also does construction work, making a small income to support the family. In order to increase their income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Sary S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This couple has four children who all are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Choijilsuren

texts.en: Choijilsuren is 39 years old and lives with his wife and son in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His family lives together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His son, Puntsag, is 13 years old and attends a local secondary school. Choijilsuren operates several businesses to provide a better life for his family. He was a herder, with a few head of livestock until 2005 when he started an office supply business at a local trading center called Mon Mandal. Besides this business, he also operates a mobile dairy, meat and raw material trading business while his wife runs the office supply business. Choijilsuren has good communication skills and has many plans for the future. He says, “I would like to expand my business and my dream is to one day open my own shop.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of dairy products and meat at wholesale price, as the price is low now, and to buy a variety of stationery in Ereen, a Chinese border town.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Mrs. Lolita T. owns and operates a business selling a variety of food products in her community. She is also a BHW (Barangay Health Worker) in her village, paid an honorarium of 1,000 monthly. She is 57 years old, married and blessed with six grown-up children. She is from the village of Ospital, Aloran. Lolita earns a monthly net income of 5,000 from her business and extra income. In 2000, Lolita joined PMPC to access the programs and services of the coop. She's availing a new loan of 50,000 which will be used for additional capital for her sari-sari store and for housing renovation. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For housing renovation

loans.name: Gansuh

texts.en: Gansuh is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son, Uuganbayr, is nine years old and attends a local secondary school. His youngest son, Suhbaatar, is two years old and doesn't yet attend school. During the day, Gansuh operates a motorcycle spare parts trading business in his town. There are very few shops that sell the same products in his province, which is a great advantage for him. He has been successfully operating his business since 2003. Gansuh is taking a loan for the second time from XacBank. He has been planning to expand his spare parts trading shop.  Gansuh is a very hardworking person who has strong selling and communication skills. He is focused on the future and says, “I would like to expand my business and to build a house for my family on a plot of land that I purchased recently.” He is requesting a 300,000-tugrug loan to purchase more motorcycle spare parts at wholesales prices in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and resell them at his shop for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase motocycle spare parts

loans.name: Lerica

texts.en:
Mrs. Lerica M. is from the village of Ospital, Aloran. She is 49 years old. She is married and blessed with three adult-aged children. She owns and operates a business selling a variety of food products in the local community. She earns a monthly net income in the amount of 3,000 PHP from this business and receives a remittance from her daughter abroad in the amount of 10,000 PHP monthly. In 2000, she joined PMPC to access the programs and services of the COOP. She's availing a new loan in the amount of 50,000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital of her existing business (a sari-sari store) and for housing renovation. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store and housing renovation

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 34-year-old single man living with his two parents. In 2008, he opened an internet café and an amusement center where he receives the village guys who come to have a nice time in his shop. He opened this kind of business after seeing a need for such services in the region. And his plan was good, because his new business has a good demand from his clients. 

Today, Mahmoud is asking to borrow $1,000 to ameliorate his business level and bring new games to attract more clients.

loans.use: To buy new games

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drugs, drinks, groceries and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Marylou's Group

texts.en:
Marylou C. is from the village of Dioyo. She is 28 years old. Marylou is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marylou is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marylou owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector making & selling "nipa", a native roof, in their community. Marylou has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Marylou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marylou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for the business. Marylou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Marylou from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve their living situation. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for expansion of the business

loans.name: Tseinpil

texts.en: Tseinpil is a 50-year-old widow and lives with her three children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Tseinpil operates a clothing trading business at a local market. She sells a range of women and men's clothing as well as underwear at her rental counter. She started her business in 2008. Currently she purchases clothing to sell to her customers once every month or two, depending on sales. Tseinpil has strong sales and communication skills. She says, “My dream is one day to open my own factory. In addition, the most important thing to me is to provide a good education for my children.” She is requesting a 1,400,000-tugrug loan to purchase a variety of clothing in Ereen, a Chinese border town, to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Khoeurn Yuos Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. KH. Y. is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice to earn a living. Aside from farming, she weaves mats at home. Her husband, Mr. Koeun Koy, is a construction worker who receives a small salary to support the family. 

Mrs. KH. Y. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support farming her crop and to buy piglets and pig feed. Mrs. KH. Y. is the mother of two children: one stays at home while the other one is a student at the local school. 

Mrs. KH. Y. is the village bank president who has been selected by all 15 members located in Daom village in Takeo province. Mrs. Kiek Keov is the group guarantor, so she is present in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Charlyn

texts.en: Charlyn is the mother of a 5-year-old child. She is 30 and married to Donald. She loves making dresses and she now earns money from it. She makes school uniforms and other types of clothes. She hopes for her business to prosper. She applied for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI and she will use it to buy cloth and tailoring materials. She also hopes to have her own shop someday.

loans.use: To buy cloth and tailoring materials

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Badegna, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Gonido sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des condiments alimentaires et céréales à l’image de Koumba D..
Ces femmes du groupe Badegna sont à leur quatrième prêt tout comme Koumba qui compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des sacs de céréales.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement à Fana et environs  auprès des producteurs et effectue sa  vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Badegna group are all married, average 33 years of age and four children each, and live in traditional extended families in Gonido, Fana sub-prefecture, in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of Mali). They know each other through family connections. Their trade is selling food condiments and cereals, as Koumba D. does it, for example. This would be the fourth loan for each woman in the Badegna group, just like for Koumba, who plans to use this loan to purchase bags of cereals. She usually buys her stock in and around Fana from farmers and sells from home, at the Tingolé market or at the fairs in the region, retail, for cash, and on credit, to a customer based composed of both women and men. She plans to obtain a monthly income of 15,000 West African Francs, which will be used towards daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cereals (for resale)

loans.name: Emerenciana

texts.en: Mrs. Emerenciana R. is from Balamban, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 43 years old and married with three children. One is already married and two of them are students. She operates a sari-sari store and her husband is a carpenter and a driver. Aside from her sari-sari store, she also sells gasoline and smartload. From her business, she earns approximately 5,000 a month. Emerenciana successfully repaid her previous loan of 6,000 from PMPC. As of now, she has a new loan of 7,000 from PMPC which will be used for additional capital for her business. This is her fourth loan cycle from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Horoljav

texts.en: Horoljav is 66 years old and lives with her youngest daughter Baigali-Erdene, age 24, in Hovd province, Mongolia. Together they operate a clothing trading business at a local trading center called Ih-Buyan. They have been successfully operating their business since 2008. It is a seasonal business, and the demand of her products is high especially during April and May when students purchase suits and other clothing for their graduation ceremonies. Horoljav is a very hardworking person and says, “My business is very important for me as it is the only financial source for my family. I would like to expand my business and product line in the future. In addition, I would like to improve my family's quality of life.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan for working capital to purchase more inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeb P. is 38 years old and lives in Rung village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Reang Mok, are farmers who own a 3-hectare field for growing rice to sell. Mrs. Chroeb P. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase a water machine, fertilizer, pesticide, and to hire a plowing laborer for the rice farm. Aside from farming, Mr. Reang Mok is a construction worker, earning a small income to help support the family. The couple has four children; one is seamstress in a garment factory, two are students in the local school, and the youngest is still a baby.

loans.use: To purchase a water machine, fertilizer, pesticide, and labor for their rice farm.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria L. is from the village of Mauswagon, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old and married with 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria raises cattle and livestock and earns about 1,600 PHP per month.  Gloria joined PMPC in 2004 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business . Gloria is now requesting her 10th PMPC loan, for 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a cow.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Shavarsh

texts.en: Shavarsh H. was born in 1962. He lives in Sarighugh village in the Ijevan area with his wife and son. Shavarsh also has two daughters who are already married and live separately from their parents. For several years Shavarsh worked as a motor mechanic, and now he works as a water resources inventory inspector at Sarighugh village municipality. At the same time he engages in stock-breeding and land cultivation and also pear cultivation. Shavarsh's wife and son help with the farming.  Shavarsh asks for a 300,000 AMD loan to repair his barn’s roof.

loans.use: To repair his barn roof.

loans.name: Zaya

texts.en: Zaya is 25 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Hovd province, Mongolia.  His daughter, Enhchimeg, is two years old and attends a local kindergarten. During the day, Zaya earns his living by operating an auto repair and taxi business. He has been operating this business since 2007, and has many customers because of his good service and stable operation. His business is well-known in his home and neighboring provinces. Zaya does not store large numbers of spare parts, so customers bring Zaya the parts they need and he repairs their cars. However, Zaya has been planning to purchase a large number of spare car parts to provide a more convenient service to his customers.  Besides his business, he has a few head of livestock which he uses to earn extra money for his family. Zaya is a very hardworking person and has many plans for the future. He says, “My dream is one day to open my own auto repair center. I will work hard to reach my goal and to provide a better life for my family. ” He is requesting a 770,000MNT loan to purchase spare car parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare auto parts.

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkola sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fougani, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
 Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Elles font le commerce de céréales et de charbon de bois en vue de prendre en charges une partie des dépenses de leur famille. Oumou D. qui est un des membres du groupe Benkola s’est spécialisée dans l’achat vente du charbon de bois depuis maintenant quelques années.
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités.
 Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents se sont bien  dénoués. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, Oumou D. envisage utiliser son prêt pour acheter une grande quantité de sacs de charbon de bois avec les fournisseurs et  revend sur place à  une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune à l’instar de Oumou, un bénéfice moyen de 20.000FCFA  par mois. 
Les bénéfices seront investis dans la nourriture, dans la santé et dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkola are married women who average 35 years of age and three children each. Along with their husband and children, they live in large traditional families and reside in the village of Fougani, sub-prefecture of Fana, region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another by ties of community and kinship. They do commerce in grains and charcoal with the aim of covering a portion of their family expenses. Oumou D., one of the group members, became specialized in buying and selling charcoal a few years ago. The women of the group are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, since they were concerned about having constant financial support for their businesses. They are now on their fourth solidarity loan. The preceding loans have all been settled. As for using the new loan, Oumou D. envisions using her loan to buy a large number of sacks of charcoal from suppliers and to resell them locally to a customer base composed of women and men. Just like Oumou, the group members each hope to make an average profit of 20,000 francs CFA per month. The profits will be invested in food, health care, and their work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal

loans.name: Saranhuu

texts.en: Saranhuu is 43 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Hovd province, Mongolia. Her husband Baynnamsrai operates a taxi service in their town. Saranhuu operates a clothing trading business at a local market. She sells a variety of clothes out of a rented shipping container. Furthermore, Saranhuu purchases her products in cooperation with other local clothing traders in order to share high transportation costs and reduce expenses. She started her business in 2001, and has gained much experience over the years. She has a loyal customer base because of her great communication skills and her good selection of products. Saranhuu is a great businesswoman who has been trying to build a bright future for her family.  She says the most important thing now is to be able to purchase her own shipping container for her business.  She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase summer clothing for the upcoming warm season.

loans.use: To purchase summer clothing for resale.

loans.name: Sandagsuren

texts.en: Sandagsuren is 52 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Hovd province, Mongolia.  He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Sandagsuren operates a plumbing service in his town. He has been operating his business since 1994, and has a loyal customer base because of his good service. Sandagsuren's business is seasonal, and he does not operate the plumbing service during the winter. Because of this, he started working with his wife in the local food market in 2007 in order to earn extra income for his family.  They rent the counter space for their food sales.  In addition, Sandagsuren usually runs a small grocery store in his yard, but has recently stopped temporarily because of low inventory turnover.  With spring coming,  he is concentrating back on his plumbing service and he is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase the equipment necessary to expand and improve his plumbing business. Besides running his businesses, Sandagsuren is a good husband and father and he says, "My children have all grown up and found their way in life except for my youngest daughter. I would like to be able to financially support her future life."

loans.use: To purchase plumbing equipment.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa T. K. N. is 46 years old. She lives in Mach Trang village in the Dong Anh district of Hanoi with her husband and four children. Two older sons are employed while the younger two are still attending school. She has been selling fish in the market for a number of years, and she earns a total monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND. She has been with SEDA for two years and always repays her loans punctually. In this credit cycle, she requests a loan of 8.066.000 VND to expand her business. Hopefully, that plan will turn a profit so that her family may afford to buy more household appliances.

loans.use: To expand her fish selling business.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 37 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Goni, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, de parentés et font le commerce de céréales et de condiments alimentaires. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités.
 Le groupe vient de commencer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et est à son premier prêt de groupe. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce premier prêt, Awa D.  compte acheter une grande quantité de céréales au niveau du village et ses environnants et pour les revendre sur place dans le village et aux environs à une clientèle composée de  revendeurs et de consommateurs.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune, à l’image de Awa D., un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA  par mois qui sera partagé entre  la nourriture, la santé et l’activité commerciale.
texts.en:
The members of the group Danaya are married women who average 37 years of age and three children each. Along with their husband and children, they live in large traditional families and reside in the village of Goni, sub-prefecture of Fana, region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another by ties of community and kinship. They do commerce in grains and condiments. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, since they were concerned about having constant financial support for their businesses. The group members just started with Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first group loan. As for using this first loan, Awa D. intends to buy a large quantity of grain from in and around the village and then to resell it locally to a customer base composed of retailers and consumers. Just like Awa D., the group members each believe they will make an average profit of 30,000 francs CFA per month that will be divided over food, healthcare, and commerce.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grain

loans.name: Sarangerel

texts.en: Sarangerel is 36 years old and lives with her husband in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her husband live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Sarangerel operates a tailoring business in her town. She produces a variety of clothing, but specializes in the Mongolian traditional robe (deel) with a range of designs. She started her business in 2003 after she graduated from a tailoring course at a local vocational training center. Her business is well-known  in her province and neighboring provinces. Sarangerel started renting her sales counter in 2003 in order to provide service to more customers. When her workload is high she hires another tailor to help with her business. Sarangerel has been planning to expand her business and to hire two more tailors in the future. She sells a deel for 20,000-30,000 MNT and demand for her products is high. Sarangerel is a great businesswoman with a good personality. She is focused on the future and says, “I would like to expand my business and to open my own shop in the future.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase an electric sewing machine and other necessary materials such as silk, fabric, and thread.

loans.use: To purchase an electronic sewing machine.

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Dembagnouma ont en moyenne 33 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Gonido, un des villages de la sous-préfecture de Fana (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font essentiellement le commerce du charbon de bois, la vente de galettes et de grains de céréales telle Fatoumata Z..
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, les femmes du groupe Dembagnouma sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé par Fatoumata Z., pour constituer un important  stock de céréales sèches (maïs, mil, petit mil, fonio etc.) 
Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les environnants auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elle effectue sa vente sur place (à domicile), au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women from the Dembagnouma group are on average 33 years of age and have three children each. They all live in traditional extended families in Gonido, one of the villages in the sub-prefecture of Fana (Second administrative region of Mali). These women met each other through ties of kinship and sell mostly wood charcoal, flat biscuits and cereals as Fatoumata Z. does. After having fully reimbursed their first loan, the women form the Dembagnouma group are now on their second group loan. This loan will be used by Fatoumata Z. to build up a large stock of dried cereals (corn, millet, fonio etc.). They get their supplies locally and around the village from producers and wholesalers. They sell locally (from their home), at the Tingolé market and at the neighboring fairs. They sell for cash and on credit to customers who are women and men. They are each planning to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 Francs CFA. It will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food and school fees. The rest will be reinvested in the activities.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fougani, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
 Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parentés et font le commerce de céréales et de charbon de bois. Ami Koné fait comme bien d’autres membres, l’achat et la vente de céréales telles le riz, le mil, l’arachide etc.
Ces femmes du groupe Djekafo collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités.
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le prêt précédent s’est bien dénoué. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, pour Ami Koné, elle veut acheter, une grande quantité de céréales dans le village et environs et  effectuera sa vente sur place à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Les femmes du groupe estiment réaliser en moyenne chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25.000FCFA  par mois, bien que les vendeuses de céréales espèrent avoir 30.000FCFA chacune.
Les bénéfices sont investis dans la nourriture, dans la santé et dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The members of the Djekafo group are married women, with an average age of 33 and four children on average. With their husbands and children they live in large, traditional families in the village of Fougani, sub-prefecture of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met as neighbors and through family connections, and they sell grain and charcoal. Like many other members, Ami Koné buys and sells grains such as rice, millet, peanuts, etc. The women of the Djekafo group work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure that they will always have financial support for their businesses. They are on their second group loan, and the first loan went very well. As for the use of this new loan, Ami Koné would like to buy a large amount of grains in the village and the surrounding area, then sell it there to both men and women. The women of the group estimate they will each make an average profit of 25,000 francs CFA per month, with the grain merchants hoping to make 30,000 francs CFA each. Profits are invested in food, health, and in their businesses.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grain

loans.name: Munhchimeg

texts.en: Munhchimeg is a 42-year-old widow who lives with her four children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Her family lives together in a ger (Mongolian nomadic tent) in a rented yard. One of her child receives disability payments from the government. Currently, Munhchimeg operates a shoe repair business in her town. She has been operating her business since 2003, and she has gained much experience over the past years. Munhchimeg is a very hardworking businesswoman as well as a good mother to her four children and is working hard to create a bright future for her family. She has many plans for the future and says, "I would like to create my own workplace and a plot of land with a house and yard for my family. I would work hard to improve our family's standard of living." She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase necessary materials for her shoe repair business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for shoe repair business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks, food and groceries to sell.

loans.name: D.c. Primary School, Lunsar Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers from the D.C. Primary School in Lunsar, a small town in northern Sierra Leone. This school was opened in 1988. This is the first loan this school is accessing from Kiva through SMT. School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in a business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

59-year-old Edward B. K. (pictured left) is the headmaster at the school and has been a teacher for 40 years. He was born in Lunsar and is married with six children who are now adults and on their own. Edward will use his share of the loan to buy house equipment and pieces of furniture.

(Attached to this photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy house equipment and pieces of furniture

loans.name: Tuongozane Group

texts.fr:
Mwadji M. est présidente du groupe de crédit Tuongozane, elle lève sa main sur la photo, cliente au 13e cycle, âgée de 50 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants parmi lesquels 3 étudient  dans un centre de formation professionnelle en mécanique auto et 2 font l’école normale, et 2 autres restent au village et font les travaux des champs, 1 enfant n’etudie pas . Son mari exerce le petit commerce.
Elle  a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Ce capital lui a permis d’acheter un bidon d’huile d’une valeur de 12$. Son business est de vendre l’huile de palme dans le  marché cental de Virunga . Il y a 8 ans qu’elle exerce cet activité de vente d’huile de palme.
Avec  le crédit de  l’IMF Hekima,  Mwadji M. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achétant  24 bidons d’huile de palme et 30 paires des souliers en plastic.
Mwadji M. vend également des souliers en plastic localement appelle Bodaboda ou soza pour accroitre son revenu.
Dans l’avenir, elle planifie de changer  l’activite et faire le commerce général et  s’approvisionner en Ouganda- Kampale. 
Et plus tard construire confortablement sa maison. 
Mwadji M. rémércie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grace à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants
En plus, Mwadji M.  est restée longtemps loin de ses enfants suite à la guerre en RDCongo, grace  au credit de l’IMF Hekima, elle  a aisement payé le transport  d’avion de ses enfants de Buyimayi jusqu’à Goma.
Ce groupe Tuongozane est  composé de 20 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Mwadji M. is president of the Tuongozane credit loan group (she is seen raising her hand on the picture). She is in her 13th credit loan cycle, is 50 years old and the mother of eight children, of whom three study in an auto mechanics training centre, two in the standard school system, two stay in the village and work in the fields, and one does not attend school. Her husband runs a small business. She began her own business with funds received from her husband. With this starting capital she purchased a container of palm oil worth $12. Her business is retailing palm oil at the central market in Virunga, which she has done for the past eight years. With the loan from the Hekima MFI Mwadji M. wants to increase her turnover by purchasing 24 containers of palm oil and 30 pairs of plastic sandals. She also sells plastic sandals locally called “bodaboda” or “soza” to increase her income. For the future, she plans to change activities and go into general commerce, getting her supplies from Kampala in Uganda. Eventually, she wants to build a comfortable home. Mwadji M. thanks the Hekima MFI for the loans she has received although she had no collateral, because they enabled her to meet her children’s needs. What’s more, she was separated for quite some time from her children due to the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), and the Hekima loans allowed her to pay for her children’s plane fare from Buyimayi to Goma.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 24 containers of palm oil and 30 pairs of plastic sandals

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Two By Two Group

texts.en:
Here are small-scale businesswomen from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group in order to enable them to improve their businesses both in terms of size and quality. In this way, they can make more sales, better profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

35-year-old Kadiatu S. is the leader of this group. Born in Makeni, she is married to a businessman and they have four children who are attending primary and secondary schools: three in secondary and one in primary school. Kadiatu sells slippers/flip-flops and has been doing this business for many years now. With the help of this loan, she will be able to buy dozens of slippers in a wide variety in order to develop her business.

loans.use: To buy dozens of slippers to add to her business

loans.name: Rakom Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Rakom group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. These women are petty-businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva in Sierra Leone to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 for each person in the group in order to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, they can add more goods to their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Kadiatu K.. Kadiatu is a 40-year-old woman who was born in Makeni. She is married to a professional worker and they have five children. Three of her children are attending secondary school and two are in primary school. For many years now, Kadiatu has been a businesswoman. She sells magi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), sugar etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy magi, salt, palm oil, sugar etc.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Tièssiri sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Goni, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
 Ces femmes se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles font le commerce de céréales et des condiments alimentaires tels la pâte d’arachide, les choux pommés, les tomates fraîches etc. Assan D. est l’une des femmes du groupe qui excelle dans l’achat et la vente des condiments alimentaires.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités.
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire et tous les trois prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, Assan D. compte  acheter,  une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires auprès des grossistes et effectuera sa vente sur place dans le village et  aux environs, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA  par mois. Quant à Assan D. elle espère sur 50.000FCFA. de  bénéfice qui sera partagé entre la nourriture,  la santé et  l’activité.
texts.en:
The members of the Djekafo group of the Tièssiri association are married women on average 35 years old with four children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional households and reside in the village of Fana, in the Koulikoro Region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women were acquainted as neighbors and through family ties. They retail cereals and food condiments such as peanut butter, cabbage, fresh tomatoes, etc. Assan D. is one of the women in the group who excels in the commerce of food condiments. They work with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to ensure continuous financial support for their activities. They are now requesting a fourth loan after fully reimbursing all three previous loans. With the new loan, Assan D. wants to buy a large quantity of food condiments from wholesalers, and sell locally in the village and the surrounding area, to both women and men customers Each group member hopes to reach average monthly earnings of 40,000 FCFA. As for Assan D., she is hoping for earnings of 50,000 FCFA that will be used for food, healthcare and commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food condiments

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks and pepper soup items to sell.

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 30 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Gonido sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments alimentaires (telle la présidente du groupe Kamissa Traoré), de céréales et du charbon de bois.
Ces femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de charbon de bois, des colis de condiments alimentaires et des sacs de céréales. La présidente du groupe qui est dans le créneau des condiments alimentaires compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des  colis de condiments (feuilles de baobab, poudre de Sounbala, poudre de gombo, sel de cuisine, cube maggi, etc.)
Elle s’approvisionne en condiments le plus généralement à Fana et à Bamako et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000F CFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguissèmè group are all married, are on average 35 years old with five children, and all live in traditional extended families in Gonido, in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They became acquainted through family ties, and they are retailers of food condiments (like the group’s president Kamissa Traoré), grain cereals and charcoal. The Djiguissèmè group women are requesting a fourth group loan which will serve to buy bags of charcoal, packages of food condiments and bags of grain cereals. The group’s president - who retails food condiments - will use her portion of the loan to buy packages of condiments: baobab leaves, Sounbala powder (a very nutritious condiment, made from seeds of the néré tree), okra powder, kitchen salt, Maggi cubes, etc. She gets her condiment supplies mainly from Fana and Bamako, and sells locally at the Tingolé market and in surrounding market fairs, for cash, retail and on credit, to both women and men customers. She hopes to reach an average monthly income of 30,000 FCFA, which will be used for daily family expenses, the remainder being reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food condiments

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè de l’association Sabougnouma, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sirimou, sous préfecture de Fana; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de céréales et du charbon de bois. 
Les céréales (arachides, mil, maïs, fonio, sésame) constituent l’activité de prédilection de Tata Temeté un des membres fondateurs du groupe.
Ces femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursés les trois précédents. Tata Temeté compte  utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des sacs de céréales sur place dans le village et dans les environnants. Elle effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 22.500FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguissèmè group of the Sabougnouma association are all married, are on average 33 years old with four children, and all live in traditional extended families in Sirimou, in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They became acquainted through family ties and trade grain cereals and charcoal. Trading cereals (peanuts, millet, corn, fonio, and sesame) is the preferred activity of Tata Temeté, one of the group’s founding members. The Djiguissèmè group women are requesting a fourth group loan, having fully repaid all three previous loans. Tata Temeté will use her portion of the loan to buy bags of cereals locally, in the village and the surrounding area. She sells locally at the Tingolé market and in surrounding market fairs, for cash, retail and on credit, to both women and men customers. She hopes to reach an average monthly income of 22,500 FCFA which will be used for daily family expenses, the remainder being reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain cereals

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguiya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sirimou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de sacs de charbon de bois et de céréales tels Awa C..
 Après trois prêts tous correctement remboursés, ces femmes du groupe Djiguiya sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire et Awa C. compte utiliser le sien  pour acheter, des sacs de céréales au niveau du village et dans les environs. Elle effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguiya group are all married, are on average 33 years old with four children, and all live in traditional extended families in Sirimou, in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They became acquainted through family ties and trade charcoal and grain cereals like Awa C.. After fully reimbursing three previous loans, the Djiguiya group women are requesting a fourth group loan. Awa C. will use her portion of the loan to buy bags of cereals locally, in the village and the surrounding area. She sells locally at the Tingolé market and in surrounding market fairs, for cash, retail and on credit, to both women and men customers. She hopes to reach an average monthly income of 20,000 FCFA which will be used for daily family expenses, the remainder being reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain cereals

loans.name: Keleya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Keleya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 38 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sirimou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des céréales, du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois. Les céréales constituent l’activité dominante de certains membres du groupe tels Djenebou F..
Ces femmes du groupe Keleya sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les trois précédents.
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, Djenebou F. compte acheter, des sacs de céréales dans le village et environs. Elle effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women from the Keleya group are all married, they average 38 years of age and three children each. They live in traditional extended families in Sirimou, sub-prefecture of Fana, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of kinship and sell cereals, firewood and wood charcoal. The cereals are the main activity of some members of the group as it is for Djenebou F.. The women from the Keleya group are on their fourth solidarity loan after having fully reimbursed the four previous ones. As for the use of this new loan, Djenebou F. is planning on buying bags of cereals in the village and its surroundings. She sells locally, at the Tingolé market and at the neighboring fairs. She sells for cash and on credit to a customer base that is men and women. She is planning on making a monthly profit of 30,000 Francs CFA, which will be used for the family daily expenses. The rest will be reinvested in the retail activities.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en: Sulaiman is a very hard working woman and she makes sure she has food on the table everyday through her hard work. She lives in Ibadan town, in Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells yam and she loves her business. She has been in this business for over 15 years, and with LAPO for the past 2 years. She is 60 years old, married, and has 4 children. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more yams to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell.

loans.name: Kyehemba Turihamwe Group Of Kyenjojo

texts.en:
It’s now two-and-a-half years since an evergreen and enterprising N. Christopher embarked on his produce sales business in Kyakaitaba in Kyenjojo district.

With nostalgia, this 47-year-old happily married father of seven kids recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as his business now has diminishing returns. A testament is the 30,000 shillings he is earning now. This is in sharp contrast to the 100,000, he says he was making at the start of his business.

There is always a story connected with people in western Uganda who, despite laboring under such tough times, find a way of educating their children. Christopher is no exception. What he is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing his business by buying more maize, beans, cassava and other crops with the proceeds of this loan.

loans.use: To buy additional produce like maize and beans to sell

loans.name: Adelere

texts.en: Adelere is a business woman who has been grinding food like tomatoes. seeds, pepper, meat, beans, etc., for her customers. She is 56 years old, married, and has 4 children. She lives in Ibadan town, in Oyo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for the past 20 years and with LAPO microfinance for over 2 years. Her greatest joy is the one on one interaction she has with the customers. Adelere is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase a grinding machine. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine.

loans.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Lafia de l’association Sabougnouma, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sirimou sous préfecture de Fana,  Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des céréales et du charbon de bois à l’image de Mah D..
Ces femmes du groupe Lafia sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire et Mah D. compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, des chargements de charrettes en  charbon de bois.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement sur place et dans les environnants et sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Mah compte réaliser comme d’ailleurs les autres membres du groupe Lafia, chacun, un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 29 000F CFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women in the Lafia group of the Sabougnouma association are all married, average 37 years of age and four children and live in traditional extended family in Sirimou, Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (the second administrative region of Mali). They know each other through family connections. Their business is sell cereals and wood charcoal, as for example, Mah D. does. This would be the fourth joint loan for the Lafia group and Mah D. plans to use hers to purchase wagonloads of charcoal. She usually purchases her stock at home and in her neighbourhood and sells also from home, at the Tingolé market and the local fairs, retail, in cash and on credit, to a client base composed of both men and women. Like each other member of the Lafia group, Mah plans to obtain a monthly benefit of 29,000 Central African Francs, which will be used towards daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing wood charcoal (for resale)

loans.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Lafia de l’association Tièssiri sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 37  ans et 5 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Goni, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
 Ces femmes se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles font le commerce de céréales et de charbon de bois. Mama S., la présidente du groupe est un des éléments qui excelle beaucoup dans l’achat vente des céréales dans lequel elle est très sollicitée et appréciée.
Les femmes du groupe Lafia collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités.
 Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt, et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, Mama S. compte acheter, une grande quantité de céréales auprès des producteurs du village et  environs et revend sur place dans le village et dans les foires environnantes à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elle estime réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30.000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture,  la santé et l’activité.
texts.en:
The members of the Lafia Group of the Tièssiri association are married women with an average age of 37 years and 5 children on average. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the village of Goni, in the subprefecture of Fana in the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other due to familial and neighborly ties. They sell cereals and charcoal. Mama S., the president of the group, does well in the cereal business and is very well known and visited. The women of the Lafia group are collaborating with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, so as to have constant financial support for their activities. They are requesting their fourth loan and all of their previous loans were repaid in full. With this new loan, Mama S. hopes to buy a large amount of cereals from growers in the village and nearby, which will be sold on-site in the village and in the surrounding marketplaces to a client base consisting of both men and women. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA. The profits will be used for food, health, and the business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Wassa Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Wassa sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fougani, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali.
 Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles font le commerce de céréales et de charbon de bois. Nana D. est un des membres qui fait le commerce de charbon de bois. 
Nana tout comme les autres membres du groupe  collabore avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités.
 Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt et tous les prêts précédents se sont  bien dénoués. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, Nana compte  acheter, des chargements de charrettes en sacs de charbon de bois avec les producteurs du village et environs et revend sur place à une clientèle composée essentiellement de revendeurs.  
Elle estime réaliser  un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont investis dans la nourriture, dans la santé et dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The members of the Wassa group are married women with an average age of 38 years and 3 children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the village of Fougani, in the Fana subprefecture, in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other due to familial and neighborly ties. They sells cereals and charcoal. Nana D. is one of the members who sells charcoal. Nana, like the other members of the group, is collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to have constant financial support for their activities. They are on their fourth loan and all of their previous loans were repaid in full. With this loan, Nana hopes to buy cartloads of charcoal from producers in the village and surrounding areas, which will then be sold on-site to a client base comprised mainly of retailers. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA. The profits will be invested in food, health, and the business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell.

loans.name: Ayobami

texts.en: Ayobami is 35 old, married, and has 4 children. She lives in Ibadan town, in Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells medicine and she has been in this business for the past 10 years. Ayobami is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She is requesting for the loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thanks to you all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell.

loans.name: Dibor

texts.en: Dibor S. is 55 years old, married and the mother of four. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has always paid back her loans on time. Her main activity consists of buying and reselling eggs. Dibor S. wants to use this loan to buy more eggs. The revenues from this activity allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase eggs

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is a 36-year-old married woman and mother of four young children. In order to help with her family’s expenses, she has established in 2007 a small headscarf and handkerchief shop in her town. Her shop targets the Islamic community in her town. Here she sells to the ladies all types, designs and quality of headscarves. She’s thankful for her business because it allows her to relieve the burden of the household expenses. 

Today, Rita is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase more merchandise for her business, specifically to increase her selection of new collections to attract more clientele and develop liquidity in her work.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Elisabeth Coumba

texts.en:
Elisabeth Coumba D. is a 67-year-old widow and mother of eight. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has paid back all of her previous loans on time.

Madame D. runs a small shop in which she sells fabric and appliances. She plans to use this loan in equal parts for the purchase of fabric and appliances.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and appliances

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer is a 25-year-old single man living with his parents and three brothers. He started his business by selling electricA. equipment from his home.  In 2008, he then rented a small shop to display his electricA. products. Now he also sells electricA. tools and home electricA. products. He works with his father and brothers to satisfy the family's needs. 

Samer is now requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase more products so he can offer a wider variety to his clients. He has informed the Loan Officer that he's planning to open a larger shop in the future and he's working hard to get to this point.

loans.use: To purchase more products for resale

loans.name: Ndèye Tening

texts.en:
Ndèye Tening F. is 41 years old, married and the mother of nine children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has always paid back her loans on time.

Ndèye Tening F. sells fabrics, jewelry and objects of art. She will use this loan to increase the stock of products in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and jewelry for sale

loans.name: Sargis

texts.en:
Sargis N. is 32 years old and lives in Ijevan city. He is married and has a son. For several years Sargis worked as a crane driver, after which he worked as head of security at one of the Ijevan companies.

Since 1993, Sargis and his parents have established their own business: fruit and vegetable trading at the Ijevan food market. With the profit from his business, Sargis has been able to start building his own shop and to support his family. He is asking for a 400,000 AMD loan to buy fruit and vegetables to resell. He intends to use his future income to finish building his own shop.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is a 55-year-old married man and the father of four school-age children. He started working repairing car bodies and painting cars 47 years ago when he was too young. In 2000, he became economically able to open his own car repair shop and to make his own profit. 

Today, Mostafa is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy a specialized machine for repairing cars. This machine will help him a lot in developing his business and presenting a new service for his customers.

loans.use: To buy a specialized machine for repairing cars

loans.name: Boudy

texts.en:
Boudy S. is a 44-year-old married mother of one child. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has paid back her previous loans on time.

Madame S. runs two businesses: a small restaurant and a stand where she sells jewelry products and fabrics when the restaurant is closed. With this loan, she will buy food for her restaurant and products to bolster her shop. The earnings from these activities will help her to pay for her family's daily needs.

loans.use: To purchase food for her restaurant and products for her shop

loans.name: Alec

texts.en:
Alec is a 35-year-old single man living with his parents. He has owned a car repair shop since 1991. He repairs all types of car and is well known in his region and its surroundings. Alec is pleased with his decision to take out his first Kiva loan from Ameen. He has been very reliable with his repayments and has actually repaid his loan in full several months early. 

Today, Alec is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a scanner machine in order to integrate this technology into his work, developing it to meet the requirements of the market and of his customers.

loans.use: To purchase a scanner machine

loans.name: Progrès Plus Group

texts.en:
Bernard B. is 53 years old, married and the father of four children, whose ages range between 12 and 23 years old. All of them attend college. He is the leader of the community bank named “Progrès Plus” which is French for “Progress”. Progrès Plus comprises 24 members who are united in solidarity in receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses. Bernard has been a micro-entrepreneur since 2003. He runs a general store to the south-west of Kinshasa. He works hard with good management skills in order to achieve his goal of one day opening a large store in his locality. He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business which earns him $130 per week.

Bernard is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having obtained and correctly repaid six loans. With his next loan, he will increase his stock of merchandise by buying two sacks of rice, ½ sack of salt and two bags of soap and reselling them at a profit.

loans.use: To increase his stock by buying rice, salt and soap

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ralph

texts.en:
Ralph is a 25-year-old single man living with his family. He learned interior design as his major and has been working on a freelance basis since 2005. He does special projects and works on all the details of the design to be presented to customers. Like the majority of young men in Lebanon, he participates in the household with his family. 

Today, Ralph is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase a new laptop to help provide various types of reports for members of his community. He’s certain that the new laptop will allow him to take on more projects and present his services more quickly to customers.

loans.use: To purchase a new laptop

loans.name: Sadio

texts.en: Sadio D. is a 53-year-old mother of four from the village of Nianing in Senegal. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has paid back her previous loans on time. Madame D. sells dried fish and oysters, an activity in which she is very experienced. She plans to use the loan to buy fish and oysters which she will resell. With the revenue from this activity, she hopes to be able to cover her children's medical expenses.

loans.use: To purchase fish and oysters

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.es:
El señor Eugenio vive en casa propia con sus hermanos es huérfano de padres, vive en la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que realiza es la venta de productos en una tienda que instalo en su casa.

El crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital para abastecer su tienda con más productos y poder de esta manera tener mayor clientela ya que es su única fuente de ingresos.

Esta es la primera vez que solicita un crédito de Impro, vía Kiva; el carácter social del crédito ayuda para que Eugenio pueda acceder a un crédito.
texts.en:
Eugenio lives in his own home with his siblings; he has no living parents. He lives in the Villa Nuevo Potosi neighborhood in the city of La Paz. He has a business selling products from a store that is set up in his house. The loan that he requests is to increase his capital so that he can restock his store with more products and in this way have more customers, since this is his only source of income. This is the first time that he has requested a loan from IMPRO via Kiva. Eugenio's good character helped him qualify to access this credit.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase capital to buy more products for his grocery store

loans.name: Marcelo

texts.es:
El señor Marcelo Calderón vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  de San Pedro, de la ciudad de La Paz, con sus dos hijos.
El señor Marcelo trabaja como empleado en una empresa telefónica de esta ciudad, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la refacción de las gradas de la casa donde vive, ya que por la antigüedad de la construcción se encuentra deteriorado.
Esta es la sexta vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Marcelo Calderón lives with his 2 children in his parents' house in the San Pedro neighborhood of the city of La Paz. Marcelo works as an employee in a telecommunications company in this city, and his income supports his family. The loan he requests is to renovate the stairs in his home, since his home was built a long time ago and the stairs are deteriorated. This is the 6th time that he has requested a loan, and he was qualified favorably by a socioeconomic analysis conducted by IMPRO to access this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to renovate the stairs in his home

loans.name: Kyabugimbi Group Of Bushenyi

texts.en:
A determined and very ambitious T. Madina, aged 33 years, is married with four children and two helpless dependents.

Madina has operated a retail shop business for five years in Kyabugimbi town, Bushenyi District. At the end of every month she is able to fetch profits to the tune of 40,000 Ugandan shillings (approximately 20 USD).

Madina’s main drawback has been having small stock in her business that cannot match the consumption rate of her customers. She is therefore seeking a loan that she figures will help her to stock more goods that will satisfy her customers’ high demand and also transform her enterprise into a wholesale business.

Being very committed to her business with good customer care, Madina hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a fundamental change in her business and enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life and to cater for her family requirements.

loans.use: To purchase new stock for her retail shop

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel, popularly called Emma, is truly a hard worker. He is 33 years old and sells building materials like plywood, nails, carpentry tools, paint etc. to customers in his neighborhood in Kumasi. Emma has been operating his trade for ten years and is eager to be taking out this loan. He plans to use this loan to add the sale of cement to expand his product line. It is the dream of almost every Ghanaian to own his own house which makes selling building materials profitable, Emma said.

Emmanuel is married to a woman who is also a trader. They have three children from age 1 – 7 years. He says that his wife dreams of being able to generate enough profits that they will be able to educate their children to at least the tertiary school level.

loans.use: To purchase cement, plywood, nails, carpentry tools, etc.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
B. Elias is a reserved 41-year-old married father of four children. He has been operating his pork business in Kabagareme in Bushenyi district for over ten years.

Elias started his business by rearing one pig. From then onwards, his business has grown to the extent that he has been able to educate all his children. In a month, Elias reveals he makes close to 500,000 shillings. He also makes some additional income through selling firewood.

Elias’s future plans are to expand his business by buying more pigs. With this loan he is optimistic that his blueprint future projects will materialize.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Tuzinduke Group

texts.fr:
N. Jeanne est une burundaise âgée de 48 ans.  Elle habite le quartier Cibitoke (Bujumbura-Ville).  Elle est mariée à un menuisier et elle est une tailleuse.  Elle préfère le métier qui la permet de travailler avec ses mains a la machine au lieu d’un travail intellectuel.  En 2002, elle a ouvert son propre atelier surnomme « L’Atelier de Couture chez Maman Anitha, » le nom de son premier enfant.

Elle est mère de 7 enfants dont 3 garcons et 4 filles.  Un seul entre eux n’est pas allé a l’ecole ; tous les autres sont a l’ecole et un seul suit les études de droit a l’universite.  Au début de la crise politico-sociale burundaise (1994), toute la famille se refugiee en RDC.  Au retour en 2000,  elle a continue son métier de tailleur avec une expérience de 12 ans.

Elle compte, avec le crédit Kiva, augmenter son capital et son business en achetant des chaussures, pagnes, et tissus en provenance de l'Ouganda pour les vendre au Burundi.  Ensuite elle a deja planifie d’ouvrir un magasin propre a elle au marche central de Bujumbura.  Alors que son mari est chômeur pour le moment, Jeane supporte toutes les charges de la famille y compris les frais de scolarité, le loyer de la maison de son fils a l’universite, et surtout la ration alimentaire.  

Elle salue beaucoup l’initiative de Turame qui tend a lutter contre la pauvreté et soutenir les petits commerçants.

Elle fait parti du groupe Tuzinduke, qui veut dire en Kirundi « Levons-nous tot le matin. »  Les membres sont dans leur deuxième cycle avec Turame.
texts.en:
N. Jeanne is a Burundian aged 48. She lives in the Cibitoke neighborhood (Bujumbura-City center). She is married to a carpenter and is herself a tailor She prefers this trade which allows her to work with her hands and on a sewing machine over an white-collar job. In 2002, she opened her own workshop that she calls "Maman Anitha's Sewing Workshop"--named after her first child. Jeanne is the mother of 7 children, three boys and four girls. Only one of them did not attend school. All the others are enrolled in school and one is studying law at the university. At the beginning of the socio-political crisis in Burundi (1994), the whole family took refuge in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Coming back in 2000, Jeanne continued to work as a tailor with 12 years' experience. With the Kiva loan, she intends to add to her capital and grow her business, buying shoes, lengths of African print cloth, and fabric coming from Uganda to sell in Burundi. After that, she already has plans to open a shop of her own in the central market of Bujumbura. Since her husband is presently out of work, Jeanne is the sole breadwinner for the family, paying school fees as well as the rent for the living quarters for their son who is studying at the university, and of course their food. Jeanne is very grateful for the Turame initiative which aims to reduce poverty and support small businesspeople. She is part of the Tuzinduke group, a word that means in Kirundi "Let's Rise and Shine". Its members are on their second loan with Turame.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing cloth and shoes for resale

loans.name: Codou

texts.en: Codou B. is 44 years old, divorced and the mother of six children. What's more, she is also responsible for four of her grandchildren. She lives in the village of Nianing on the Atlantic coast of Senegal. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has always paid back her loans on time. Codou B. sells jewelry at a stand and, as a second occupation, she sells peanut butter. She will use this loan to buy more of these products. The revenue generated by this activity will allow her to cover her family's daily needs.

loans.use: To buy products to sell

loans.name: Adom Wo Wim Group

texts.en:
Paul is thirty-six years old. He is married and blessed with three children who are all currently in the basic school. The last born is seven years. Paul lives with her wife and the children in a rented apartment in the community. His wife trades in textile materials and clothes to help him to take good care of the family. 

Paul is a very hard-working man. He trades in Chinese products such as food supplements. He has been running this business for three years and aspires to develop his business to the level of a clinic. He is hopeful to give all his children the best education he can afford. 

He requests a loan to procure additional products in bulk to scale up his business.

Paul is the leader of a four-member trust bank group called ‘Adom wo wim’, meaning 'help comes from above'. The group members are mainly into trading activities. It is the dream of the members of this group to access this loan so as to procure goods in bulk to increase their stocks.

loans.use: to buy Chinese food supplements

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more guinea corn to process Kunu to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes, bags and sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Da Dwene Group

texts.en:
