Teresita P. is from the village of Macabayao, Jimenez Mis. Occ.. She is 42 years old. Teresita is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Teresita P. Group.

Teresita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell in the future. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Teresita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About PMPC:

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

texts.en:
Donatela R. is from the town of Villa Ylanan Maddela Quirino. She is 56 years old and the leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Donatela is married and has six adult children. To make a living, she sells seafood products including fish and shrimp in her local community. She has had this business for over five years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Donatela joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Donatela is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Donatela from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
In 2003, Erlinda joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.) a microfinance institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. As a member of ASHI for almost seven years, she has shown very good performance in her attendance at center meetings, weekly repayments, and her business still exists; therefore, she is qualified to obtain larger loans.

Erlinda runs a variety store. She wants to continue her business; it gives them a good income to support the education needs of of her grandchildren. She is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000.00 to use for additional capital to improve her business and her income. She dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it to other villages. Her five children and grandchildren are her inspiration to continue with her variety store business. She now feels very happy with the services of ASHI and KIVA partner. It gives them a big opportunity to pursue their family dreams. She hopes that they continue the service for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead.

loans.use: To use for additional working capital to improve her business and her income.

loans.name: Najil Bantilan Group

texts.en:
Najil B. is from the village of Taboo, Jimenez. She is 33 years old. Najil is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Najil B. Group.

Najil is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Najil owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Najil has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Najil joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Najil has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Najil is requesting a new loan of 30,500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Najil from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is widowed. She has one adult son. Oksana sells women's clothing at village markets. Her monthly income today is about 6,000 UAH.

Oksana started this business 14 years ago, when she saw a demand for clothing outside of her town, in local villages. She began to travel out to these villages offering women's clothing. The clients were thankful because they did not want to spend their time going to the town to buy clothing. This business became a stable source of income for Oksana and her growing son.

Oksana would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase the assortment. She wants to offer a larger variety to her clients to satisfy their demands.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing for sale.

loans.name: Liberato

texts.en:
Liberato T. is from the village of Brgy, Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 50 years old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Liberato has a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Liberato joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liberato is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan he has taken out from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Jocelyne N. is from the village of Brgy, Sto.Domingo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old and the leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jocelyne is married and has two school-aged children. She makes a living from her business selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste. She has had her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Jocelyne joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyne has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Jocelyne is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP which will also be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the eleventh loan taken out by Jocelyne from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product line

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody R. is a 39-year-old strong woman with the faith and determination to get out from the ties of poverty. She is a mother of 5 young children.

As a mother of big dreams, in 2005 she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), a microfinance institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since then, she has started selling rice and fish and this really helps them to meet their needs.

Now Melody requests her 5th loan for 15,000 PHP to purchase more inventory for her business. Specifically she will buy 8 sacks of rice and fresh fish.

She hopes that with the help of ASHI and KIVA she can reach her ambition to step out from poverty, expand her business, and pay for the needs of her five children in school until they complete their college degrees.

loans.use: To buy 8 sacks of rice and fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
To supply additional income, Ofelia D. M. wants to expand the family retail business with working capital from Kiva through ASHI. Ofelia requests a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase inventory of assorted goods for her store. She believes that having additional stocks will increase revenue and profits for the family’s retail business.

Since 2007, Ofelia has achieved strong performance with regular attendance to group meetings and steady repayments. She is thankful for secure access to capital and loans to support her goals in life. Ofelia is seen old at her age but also strong and a woman of courage to battle challenges in order to achieve her goals. She is a caring mother to 5 adult children. Ofelia enjoys considering that the loan from ASHI and KIVA partner will change their lives and provide for her family's needs.

loans.use: To purchase inventory of assorted goods for her store.

loans.name: Roya Lema Group

texts.en:
Lema is the group leader of Roya Lema group. She lives in district 9 of Kabul Afghanistan. She is married with four children who are in school, and she supports all her family members through her monthly income.

Lema is a carpet weaver and would like to expand her business. She needs the loan to buy good quality weaving materials and then weave her carpets which are in high demand in the bazaar.

She wants to grow her business and to support her children with a better education.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for weaving carpets.

loans.name: Hadaf-E-Nek Group

texts.en:
Palwasha is the group leader of Hadaf-e-Nek Group. She lives in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is 35 years old and is married with seven children.

Palwasha is a carpet weaver and, through her business, she earns money to support the essential requirements of her family members.

Palwasha wants to expand and progress her business and for the purpose of increasing her business and adding to her monthly income she wants to receive this Kiva loan. She thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To complete the essential requirements of her business

loans.name: Gulzaina's Group

texts.ru:
Гульзайна Жакыпова– лидер данной группы. Она вместе с семьёй проживает в г. Балыкчи. Гульзайне тридцать семь лет. Она воспитывает трёх дочерей. Все её дети учатся в школе. Старшая дочь учится в восьмом классе, средняя – в четвёртом, а младшая дочь учится в третьем классе. Гульзайна – вдова. Поэтому, чтобы прокормить семью, ей приходится думать как минимум за двоих. Ранее, она взяла кредит в размере пяти тысяч сомов ($ 100) в микро кредитной организации и купила телёнка. С тех пор она активно начала заниматься увеличением поголовьем скота и сейчас её скот находится под присмотром её родителей, проживающих в селе. Сейчас у Гульзайны есть две коровы, один телёнок и шесть баранов. И этого всего она добилась за четыре года. А сама Гульзайна не стала сидеть, сложа руки, и устроилась в частную баню банщицей. Гульзайна очень хочет увеличить поголовье скота и тем самым приобрести финансовую независимость. Для неё скот является хорошим активом, который позволил бы ей в дальнейшем финансировать образование детей или позволил бы ей начать другой вид мелкого бизнеса. Она верит, что с нынешними темпами, вполне реально в будущем перепродать скот и купить квартиру. На данный момент Гульзайна нуждается в кредите. Она хотела бы вложить средства в покупку четырёх баранов, чтобы в дальнейшем их перепродать. 

У Гульзайны три партнёра по группе:

Жанаркул Идирисовой сорок шесть лет. У Жанаркул двое детей. Сыну тринадцать лет и дочери пять. Жанаркул вместе с мужем торгуют домашней утварью. Это приносит им около полторы тысячи сомов. Жанаркул из – за зимнего периода не торговала , и сейчас надеется получить кредит, и восстановить бизнес. 

Гульмире Орузбаевой пятьдесят лет. Гульмира – мать двоих сыновей. Гульмира начала свой бизнес с того, что закупила 1000кг.рыбы и продавала на дому по пять сомов за штуку. Сейчас она уже имеет постоянный доход в размере двенадцати тысяч сомов. Ей требуется кредит , чтобы оплатить услуги стоматолога. Гульмира планирует в ближайшем будущем обучить детей в ВУЗах, а также построить баню.

Чолпон Кадыровой тридцать шесть лет. Супруг Чолпон – частный предприниматель. Он также по выходным топит баню для клиентов. Чолпон арендует кафе и предоставляет услуги общественного питания: готовит блюда европейской и  национальной кухни. Чолпон хочет получить кредит и  купить авто для мужа. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Gulzaina J. is the leader of this group. She lives together with her family in the city of Balykchi. She is thirty-seven years old. Gulzaina is raising three daughters, all of whom attend school. The oldest daughter is in eighth grade, the middle is in fourth, and the youngest daughter is in third grade. Gulzaina is a widow. This is why she has to come up with at least twice as much to support her family. Previously, she obtained a loan in the sum of five thousand som ($100) at a micro financing organization and bought a calf. Since then, she actively started increasing her livestock headcount, and now her livestock is in her parents’ care in a village. Currently, Gulzaina has two cows, one calf and six sheep. And she achieved all this in four years. Gulzaina also decided not to stay put and got a job as an attendant at a sauna. She wants to increase her livestock headcount and, thus, achieve financial independence. Livestock is a good asset for Gulzaina, which would hopefully let her finance her children’s education in the future or start another type of small business. She believes that with the current tempo, it is realistic to resell livestock in the future and purchase an apartment. Currently, Gulzaina needs a loan. She wants to invest money into purchasing four sheep for subsequent resale. Gulzaina has three partners in the group: Janarkul I. is forty-six years old. She has two children. Her son is thirteen years old and daughter is five. Janarkul and her husband sell household goods. This yields them about a thousand and a half som. Due to the winter season, Janarkul has not been selling and hopes to obtain a loan now and rebuild her business. Gulmira O. is fifty years old. She is a mother of two sons. Gulmira started her business with a purchase of 1000 kg of fish that she sold for five som each. Now, she has a consistent income in the sum of twelve thousand som. She needs a loan in order to pay for dental service. Gulmira plans to give her children a college education in the near future and to build a sauna. Cholpon K. is thirty-six years old. Her husband is an entrepreneur. He also runs a sauna for customers on the weekends. Cholpon leases a café and provides public food service; she cooks European and national dishes. She wants to obtain a loan and buy a car for her husband.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of four sheep for subsequent resale

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en:
Jamal is a 27-year-old single man who lives with his parents and three siblings. He has been working as a mechanic for the past fifteen years, starting when he was very young. He used to go with his father to his mechanic’s shop and learned the occupation from him. He works hard to be able to finalize his home preparation and get married soon.

In order to develop his business and improve it, Jamal is asking to borrow $1,200 to buy additional iron to be able to meet the requirements of his clients and make a good income.

loans.use: To buy additional iron

loans.name: Aida's Group

texts.ru:
Человек порой находит себя довольно слабым существом, и ему и в голову не придёт попробовать пойти на смелые шаги по изменению своего будущего и кардинальному изменению своей жизни. Однако он, не смотря ни на что, продолжает поиски и в конце концов в результате стечения определённых обстоятельств и предпосылок, такая возможность появляется и именно в этот момент очень важно, чтобы человек не испугался, а смело сделал этот шаг, шаг к лучшему будущему. Лидер группы, Аида Ибрагимова, решила сделать этот шаг. Она имела уже работу и могла бы спокойно продолжать своё скромное существование. Однако в 2007 – году она устроилась на работу  в компанию, продающую косметику посредством сетевого маркетинга. Аиде тридцать лет. У неё одна дочь, которой семь лет. Дочь Аиды ходит в школу и учится в первом классе. Аида, чтобы прокормить себя и дочь, занимается торговлей косметики, а также работает помощником санитарного врача в. Её зарплата составляет две тысячи двести сомов ($50). Косметикой она занимается уже третий год и её ежемесячный доход вырос до двух с половиной тысяч сомов ($ 60). Стоит отметить, что в компании по продаже косметики, Аида занимается сравнительно новым путём торговли, а именно сетевым маркетингом.  Специфика этого вида торговли включает в себя также вложения со стороны клиента, и постоянный поиск клиентов, чтобы увеличить свой доход. И сейчас Аида нуждается в кредите, в размере шести тысяч сомов ($130), чтобы купить косметику для реализации.

Жанылбубу Токторбаевой сорок шесть лет. Жанылбубу – мать двоих сыновей. Оба ходят в школу. Старший сын в этом году заканчивает школу. Жанылбубу дома шьёт национальные изделия, а также берёт заказы у постоянных клиентов. Жанылбубу просит выделить ей кредит для покупки ткани для пошива. 

Кулай Абдылдаевой сорок шесть лет. Муж Кулай  работает сварщиком. Кулай и её муж вырастили двоих детей. Чтобы помочь мужу содержать семью, Кулай хочет устроиться на работу в завод по производству спирта. Кулай нуждается в кредите, чтобы оплатить контракт за обучение снохи в размере 20000 сомов.

Гульнур Курманбаевой двадцать пять лет. У Гульнур двое детей. Оба её детей ходят в садик. Муж Гульнуры занимается откормом и перепродажей скота. Два года назад он купил корову и удачно продав, начал закупать крупно – рогатый скот специально для откорма и перепродажи. Гульнур обратилась за кредитом, чтобы купить две коровы. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Sometimes a person may feel like a fairly weak being, and it will not even enter his mind to take brave steps in order to change the future and significantly change his life. However, despite all the obstacles, he continues searching and finally finds that opportunity as a result of certain circumstances and conditions. It is especially important that at this moment, a person would not get scared, but would take this brave step, the step toward a better future. The leader of the group, Aida I., decided to take this step. She already had a job and could have calmly continued her modest existence. However, in 2007, she found a job at a company that sold cosmetics through network marketing. Aida is thirty years old. She has a seven-year-old daughter, who currently attends school and goes to first grade. In order to support herself and her daughter, Aida is involved in cosmetics sales and also works as an assistant to a sanitary physician. Her salary is two thousand two hundred som ($50). She has been involved in cosmetics sales for the third year already, and her monthly income increased to two and a half thousand som ($60). It should be noted that at the cosmetics sales company, Aida is involved in a fairly new way of sales, network marketing. The specifics of this type of sales include input from the client and a constant search for customers in order to increase income. And now Aida needs a loan in order to purchase cosmetics for sale. Janylbubu T. is forty-six years old. She is a mother of two sons, both of whom attend school. The oldest son will be graduating from school this year. Janylbubu sews national dresses at home and also gets orders from her permanent customers. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of fabric for sewing. Kulay A. is forty-six years old. Her husband works as a welder. Kulay and her husband raised two children. In order to help her husband support the family, Kulay wants to find a job at the alcohol manufacturing plant. She needs a loan in order to pay her daughter-in-law’s education contract. Gulnur K. is twenty-five years old. She has two children, both of whom go to a kindergarten. Gulnur’s husband is involved in livestock fattening and sales. Two years ago, he bought a cow, successfully sold it and then started buying cattle specifically for fattening and resale. Gulnur requested the loan in order to buy two cows.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Salem Group

texts.en:
Homa is the group leader of Salem Group. She is 45 years old and lives in 16th district, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with three children: two sons and one daughter, who are students in school..

Homa wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy necessary materials for her business and wants to increase the size of her new shop and buy a new machine as well. She hopes to expand and progress her business and to have more clients, too.

Homa thanks AFS and all Kiva lenders for this loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for her business

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 35 years old and married with three children who go to school.

Isaac sells timber to earn a living. He has been in this business for ten years and has one employee. He had previously taken out a loan of Kes 80,000 from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business and which he successfully repaid.

Isaac hopes to expand his business and improve his living standards in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a sanding machine and more timber.

loans.use: To purchase a sanding machine and more timber

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en: It is delightful to see people striving to improve their living conditions. Probably the main factor driving these people to go forward is the sole conviction of these people that they deserve something better in this life than to just obtain allowances from Government and wait for better times. Maybe another factor which makes these people different from the crowd is their feeling of responsibility for the future of their children. They feel themselves responsible for building a decent life for the sake of the wellbeing of their children. Aigul T., the leader of this group, is forty-three years old and is divorced. She has a daughter who has turned twenty-one and who works in a private company, obtaining a salary of $60. Aigul trades in vegetables at the market and her income is somewhere around $175 a month. During summertime her daughter helps her in the business. Aigul started selling vegetables fifteen years ago. During this time she has been able to buy a two-room flat (apartment) and see her daughter married. Aigul wants to expand her assortment of vegetables and therefore decided to apply for this loan. One of her future plans is to send her daughter to college. Aigul’s partners are: Cholpon O., 41, is the mother of two children, both of whom go to school. Her husband is retired and receives a pension. She works as a teacher and also trades in cosmetics, selling to her colleagues at school. She needs a loan to increase her turnover. Damira A., 41, has four daughters. Her husband provides welding services while Damira stays at home with a child. She and her husband have been able to buy a house, even though their salaries are not so high. Now Damira needs a loan to buy a circular. Juma M., 51, is a taxi-driver. He manages to earn two to three dollars a day. His spouse is a housewife and they have two children. His elder son is also a driver, working in the capital. Juma needs a loan, as he plans to buy a battery. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To expand her assortment of vegetables

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer is a 30-year-old single lady who owns a pharmacy in Kibera slums. She also sells mobile phone accessories to earn extra income. Besides that, she rents out sewing machines to get more income.

Jenifer was previously employed before she saw the need of having her own business. Her business, which has been running for five years, has really expanded since she joined Faulu Kenya. She uses her income to pay wages to her employee and to improve her living standards. She hopes to open up her own clinic in the future.

Jenifer is a hardworking lady who is determined to see her business grow into a wholesale operation. She has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy anti-malarial tablets, antibiotics and syrups to stock her pharmacy.

loans.use: To buy anti-malarial drugs, antibiotics and syrups

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and animal feeds

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is 30 years old and married with two children who go to school. He runs a cafeteria in his hometown to earn a living. He has been in this business for three years and has two employees. He also keeps animals for commercial purposes to increase his income.

Jonathan hopes to grow his business and improve his living standards in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy ingredients for cooking.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for cooking

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. M. is 37 years old and married with one child who is in school. She runs a photograph studio to earn a living. She has been in this business for 10 years and has two employees.

Since Susan joined Faulu Kenya, she has acquired management skills from their training. She hopes to grow her business and double the business turnover in five years time.

She has requested a loan of 30000 KES from Faulu Kenya to buy a photocopy machine. She describes herself as hardworking and social.

loans.use: To  purchase a photocopy machine.

loans.name: Tet

texts.en:
Mr. Tet T. is 55 years old, lives in Steung Sen commune, the province of Kompong Tom. He and his wife are local cultivators who work on their own farm field. They have 5 teenage children who are no longer in school. All of them are employed at different occupations and also provide their small income to contribute to their whole family.

In addition, Tet T. owns a generator and he provides a battery charging service for extra profit. Tet T. leads his charging service very well, which several day provides him with much income.

Unfortunately, the machine recently has broken and he may need to replace some problem parts. Because Tet T. doesn’t have enough money he decided to seek a loan to pay the fee for mending his old generator.

Tet T. is not in the picture because he was busy on that day so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To pay the fees to mend his old generator.

loans.name: Asylkan's Group

texts.en:
A person without goals is like a ship without a sail. Many people these days are refrained by daily routine and daily needs and do not have high objectives toward which they would aspire. This is not the case with the heroes of our story. They represent the middle–income or even lower middle–income class and do not seem to be distinguished from other people except that they all have high objectives and the determination to achieve them.

Asylkan Y. is the group leader. She is a widow and lives with her son (16 years), grandson and daughter-in-law. Asylkan works as an accountant and also raises cattle. Two and half years ago, she bought a cow and since then she has been trying to increase the population of her livestock.

Now her accountant's salary is a little over 80 USD a month. She would like to have income from selling milk and trading in cattle during weekends at a cattle market. She has decided to apply for a loan to buy two lambs, pay a shepherd for grazing, and buy forage for them. In the future she hopes to buy a car for her son and furniture for her home.

Gulzaira T., 49, is a widow. Her son works in a resort and earns a salary of 185 USD. Gulzaira does odd jobs in some factory. She hopes to obtain this loan to buy a big carpet and some clothes.

Anarkul A., 41, is single. She keeps some cattle at her parent’s and works as a laborer in “PAT” factory. With her loan she hopes to help her sister prepare the dowry of her daughter.

Apal C., 48, is a widow. Her son works as a baker and has a salary of 95 USD. Apal is a laborer in a “PAT” company and earns a salary of around 85 USD. She will use her loan to buy a cow for feeding and resale.

======================================

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment).

It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy two lambs, pay a shepherd for grazing and buy forage.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is 38 years old and married, with two children who go to school. She earns her living by wholesale clothing sales, and her husband is employed in a hotel. She belongs to a group named Negeu where she saves part of her income and also gets business ideas. She hopes to grow her business and improve her standard of living in the future. She has requested a loan of KES 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more clothes for sale. This will be her first loan from Faulu Kenya and she is certain that it will make a difference in her business financially.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes for resale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kalira's Group

texts.ru:
Любой бизнесмен, никогда не разбрасывает деньги по ветру, а стремится вложить средства в нужное дело, чтобы эти деньги не лежали, а приносили доход. Порой именно эти деньги и становятся залогом благополучного будущего. Эти качества, а именно умение предугадать будущее, прагматичность и тонкий расчёт, отличают хороших бизнесменов от невежд. Интересно представляла ли себе Калира Ибраималиева, лидер этой группы, двенадцать лет назад, когда, она, накопив деньги со своей заработной платы, купила бычка для откорма, чтобы затем перепродать его, что это занятие в дальнейшем станет её главным источником пропитания. Сейчас Калире пятьдесят один год. Она уже не работает в учреждении, а ведёт своё хозяйство. Она вырастила одного сына, и нескольких дочерей. Сын уже женат и имеет детей. Калира ведёт активный образ жизни. Она помогает мужу и сыну ухаживать за скотом, а также занимается воспитанием внуков, а их у неё трое: две внучки и один внук. Старшие две внучки уже ходят в школу, а младшему внуку всего девять месяцев.  Калира наблюдает, как растут её внуки, и хочет подготовить для них достойное наследство. За счёт разведения скота, она дала детям образование и выдала дочерей замуж. Сейчас её ежемесячный доход составляет четыре тысячи семьсот сомов ($100). Она продолжает помогать детям. Вот и теперь Калира обратилась за кредитом, чтобы оплатить учёбу жены сына. 

Айзаде Шерипбаевой двадцать восемь лет. Айзаду постигло большое испытание на прочность, так как сейчас она одна воспитывает четверых детей, из которых двое – её дочери, а двое других её племянники. Айзада – разведена. Она разводит скот, и продаёт бычков на скотном рынке. Её доход четыре тысячи девятьсот сомов. 

Токтобю Текебаевой пятьдесят один год. Муж Токтобю торгует на рынке автозапчастями, а она сама занимается животноводством и продаёт молоко. За счёт скотоводства и продажи она зарабатывает чуть меньше пяти тысяч сомов. Токтобю надеется получить кредит, чтобы купить корову для увеличения поголовья. 

Нурлану Шериппаеву двадцать пять лет. Жена Нурлана – домохозяйка. Нурлан занимается перевозкой пассажиров. Он работал в России. Там накопил деньги, купил машину и занялся перевозкой пассажиров. Сейчас его доход составляет около шести тысяч сомов. Он обратился за кредитом, чтобы отремонтировать машину. У Нурлана растут две дочери. И он поставил себе цель – купить квартиру для своей семьи.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Any businessman would never throw money into the wind, but instead strives to invest money into a good deal, so that the money earns an income. Sometimes it is this money that becomes a deposit for a prosperous future. These qualities and especially, the ability to guess the future, pragmatism and keen calculation, differentiate good businessmen from ignorant ones. It is interesting to know whether Kalira I., the leader of this group, imagined twelve years ago, when she, having saved money from her salary, bought a bull for fattening and subsequent resale, that in the future this business would become her primary source of income. Now Kalira is fifty-one years old. She no longer works at her job, but runs her business. She raised one son and several daughters. The son is already married and has children. Kalira leads an active life: she helps her husband and son take care of livestock and also helps raise the grandchildren. She has three children: two granddaughters and one grandson. The oldest two granddaughters are already in school, and the youngest grandson is only nine months old. Kalira watches how her grandchildren grow and wants to prepare a decent inheritance for them. Thanks to her livestock business, she was able to provide her children with an education and to marry off her daughters. Currently, her monthly income is four thousand seven hundred som ($100). She continues to help her children. And now Kalira requested a loan in order to pay for her daughter-in-law’s education. Ayzada S. is twenty-eight years old. She went through a great test of endurance because now she has to raise four children by herself. Two of them are her daughters, and two others are her nephews. Ayzada is divorced. She breeds livestock and sells cows at the livestock market. Her income is four thousand nine hundred som. Toktobu T. is fifty-one years old. Her husband sells auto parts at a market, and she is involved in animal husbandry and sells milk. She earns a little less than five thousand som from the animal husbandry business. Toktobu hopes to get the loan to purchase a cow in order to increase livestock headcount. Nurlan S. is twenty-five years old. His wife is a homemaker. Nurlan is involved in passenger transportation. He used to work in Russia. He saved money there, bought a car and started the transportation business. Currently, his income is about six thousand som. He requested the loan in order to repair his car. Nurlan has two daughters. He set a goal to buy an apartment for his family.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for daughter-in-law's tuition

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Mrs. Ban P., aged 43, is a farmer. She owns a piece of farmland on which she plants many types of crops, especially rice, from which she earns a living. She has a life partner, her husband, who is helping her with her business activities. The couple has been married for many years and is blessed with five teenage kids. All of them are going to school or work as well. Ban P. will use her first loan to improve her daily profits from the farming business. She will buy insecticide, fertilizer, and seeds to improve her crop yield.

loans.use: To buy insecticide, fertilizer, and seeds to improve her crop yield.

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
The economic situation does not seem to be getting better. The fluctuation of market prices and uncertainty in the job market make it difficult for people to have a positive outlook. At these times it is necessary to look past the current opinions of society and reevaluate the situation in order to make the right decision. When we see people who, in spite of adversity, are full of energy to go ahead with building their lives, we witness again and again how people implement the famous proverb that says: it is better to light a candle than to curse the darkness.

Aigul K. is the leader of this group. She is 43 years old and has four children. Aigul is engaged in raising livestock and selling milk. Her husband helps her look after the cattle. Aigul’s eldest son (he is 22) already makes his own living by means of trade. Her daughter goes to a medical college. Another daughter goes to school and the little son stays at home. Aigul’s monthly income comes to little bit less than $130. Aigul hopes to obtain this loan to buy a cow to increase the total population of her livestock and the amount of milk for sale.

Aigul’s partners are:

Gulumjan K., 33, is the mother of three children. Her husband works in a sugar plant. Gulumjan raises livestock and takes care of her little daughter, who is just three. She has applied for this loan to buy kitchen furniture.

Surmakan J., 42, is engaged in cattle breeding. Her spouse is a farmer. Surmakan has two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son trades in the market. Surmakan needs a loan to help her husband with his farm.

Janylbu A., 56, has five children. Her elder children are married and live separately. As for her husband, he and their elder sons are occupied with cattle breeding. Janylbu sells milk and helps look after the cattle. She wants to obtain this loan in order to repair her house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the "3-Ps" concept: People (building human capital and taking care of both customers and society), Profit (to be profitable and grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a cow to increase the total population of the livestock and the amount of milk for sale

loans.name: Nickson

texts.en: Nickson is a 24-year-old single man. He runs a retail shop where he sells general merchandise such as sugar, rice, cooking fat, and cereals. He has been in this business for four years and has one employee. His business is located in the Kibera slums in Nairobi, the capital city. He hopes to grow his business and improve his living standard in the future. He has requested a loan of KES 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of sugar, cooking fat, and cereals.

loans.use: To add to his stock of sugar, soda, cereals, and cooking fat.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is 36 years old and married, with seven children. She grows tea and rears dairy cattle on her farm for commercial purposes. Her farm is located in Karatina, Central Province. She has been in this business for three years. She saves her money in a group named Step by Step where all the members are farmers. This has helped her to invest in her business. She plans to buy more dairy cattle and improve her living standard in the future. She had previously taken out a loan of KES 20,000 from Faulu Kenya, which she used to expand her business and has successfully repaid. She is now requesting a loan of KES 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a dairy cow and animal feed.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and animal feed.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea O. is a 44-year-old humble villager living in Kompong Tom province. She became a widow woman by divorcing from her husband when her kids were very young. She has three children: one works in the garment factory and other two attend the local public school.

To create a daily profit Chea O. built a stall next to her house where she raises a few pigs for slaughtering. She is able to sell her pigs twice a year. She has done this business for years.

Chea O. relys much on this business which is a significant source of family proceeds. She has goals to improve her pig trade for years but she doesn’t have any sponsor. Thus, she asks for a loan from Kiva in order to purchase pig food and a piglet for her stall.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and a piglet for her stall.

loans.name: Samarkul's Group

texts.en:
The heroes of this story are ordinary people in their communities having lives which are no different from the lives of other citizens. And still there is a distinction. This distinction comes from their intentions and an attitude they have toward their lives.

Samarkul T. is 56 years old. She is a widow and mother of 5 children. Her three daughters are married, one daughter is divorced, and her son works in a factory. Samarkul earns her livelihood by trading in convenience goods at market.

Ten years ago she started selling eggs and then switched to selling convenience goods. The trade appeared to be successful and she started to make profits. These profits allowed her to marry her daughters and son.

Now, her monthly income is around 165 USD. For Samarkul nothing is in her way to go forward and expand her trade. She has executed her obligation as a parent to marry them and help them get on their feet. Samarkul could easily have rested at home and enjoyed her old age looking after her grandchildren. Instead she decided to keep working. Moreover she has an intention to buy a pavilion. Now she needs a loan to purchase goods.

Samarkul’s partners are:

Azamat J. U., 19, is the youngest member of the group. He started his business as early as two years ago, when his mother bought two sacks of potatoes. Since then he has been making his own living and even providing for his little sister. Azamat trades in vegetables and needs a loan to buy an iron pavilion.

Almagul O., 56, has four children. She and her husband trade in vegetables at the market. The eldest son works and the rest either go to college or to school. Almagul needs this loan to purchase vegetables and increase the turnover.

Aijamal N., 28, is single. She is engaged in cattle breeding and selling milk. With the help of her father she bought a cow and since then started raising livestock. Her monthly income is about 70 USD. Aijamal needs a loan to purchase packages for sale.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment).

It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To increase the stock of convenience goods for sale.

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Women are known as the weak sex. But when it comes to reality, they prove to be at least as robust and persevering as men. Maybe they naturally tune themselves to be strong and patient in face of difficulties and obstacles in life. As a matter of fact, when needed, they can set themselves on the right frequency of determination and success.

Gulnara U. is the leader of this group. She is 46 years old. Her husband works as a builder. She has two children. Her son, 19, is a cattle breeder and her daughter is in ninth grade. Gulnara trades in forage. She used to have some cattle. Then she sold them and started the trade in coal and forage.

In their spare time her children help their mother sell the forage. During three years of trading in forage and feed, Gulnara and her husband have been able to buy a second house. Now her monthly income reaches somewhere 70 USD and that is why Gulnara wants to increase the amount of forage for sale. She hopes to use this loan to purchase more forage.

Gulnara’s partners are:

Darya B. is 19. She is single and works in a cable producing factory as a specialist–isolator. Her monthly salary is around 80 USD. She decided to apply for this loan as she plans to repair her flat, buy curtains and a DVD–player.

Svetlana D., 44, is divorced. She has two children. Both of them work and live separately. Svetlana works at a barber’s shop. She and a friend of hers decided to open their own barber shop and finally managed to accomplish this plan. Svetlana needs a loan to renew the equipment and repair the pipes.

Larisa S. is 37. She is single and has a 17–year-old daughter. Larisa works in a barber’s shop. She needs to help her friend repair the barber’s shop, but her salary is only 80 USD and therefore she hopes to obtain this loan. She plans to open a small shop.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment).

It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a larger amount of forage for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more palm oil in gallons to sell.

loans.name: Chhlat

texts.en:
Mrs. P., 26, resides in a small wooden house with other family members. The location of their house is in the rural area of Kompong Tom province, where P. has been earning a living by raising pigs. By doing this, P. has received many benefits to ensure a better standard of living for her family.

Her husband is a temporary laborer who is hired by villagers to do anything for a fee. P. became a mother of a young child four years ago. Her child is enrolled in school and dependent on her. 

Mature rice is commanding the lowest price at this time. P. would like to take this occasion to generate extra profit by looking for a loan to order and buy rice in bulk from farmers. Then she will sell it later to raise a profit. With any remaining amount of the loan, P. will improve her pig-raising business.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk and improve her pig-raising business

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth P. is from the town of Wigan Cordon. She is 32 years old and the leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elizabeth P.'s group.

Elizabeth is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a general store selling a variety of different products. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 19000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 19000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth D., 50, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Widowed and blessed with a child, she makes sure that she earns so that her family can have a better life. She has been selling health supplements and vitamins for quite some time now.

Elizabeth has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 45,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy more quantities of products that she can sell.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy her own house and lot.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying more quantities of health products that she can sell

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn O. is from the village of Brgy. Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Marilyn is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Begaim's Group

texts.ru:
Каждый день Бегаим Алиева встаёт рано утром, чтобы собрать яйца и сдать их на рынок. Это занятие приносит ей около семьсот сомов ($15) в месяц. Она – лидер данной группы. Всю свою сознательную жизнь Бегаим прожила в сельской местности и занималась сельским хозяйством. После замужества, родители ей оставили две коровы, чтобы было с чего начинать своё хозяйство. С тех пор уже прошло двадцать семь лет. Бегаим сама стала мамой и причём пятерых детей. Две дочери уже вышли замуж и живут отдельно. Сын (ему двадцать четыре), также занялся сельским хозяйством и активно помогает Бегаим ухаживать за скотом. Ещё один сын (ему пятнадцать лет), учится в восьмом классе, а самый младший сын – во втором классе. Муж Бегаим, неизменно, бок о бок, с Бегаим занимается домашним хозяйством и помогает жене воспитывать детей и вместе с сыном пытаются постоянно увеличивать поголовье скота. Их доход помимо продажи яиц, также приходит от продажи молока и доходит до двух тысяч сомов ($40) в месяц. Повседневные хлопоты совсем не утомляют Бегаим. Напротив она с радостью готова содержать больше скота и тем самым увеличить доход семьи. Да и жизнь дорожает с каждым днём и надо принимать твёрдые решения и идти дальше. Бегаим решила обратиться за этим кредитом, так как он позволил бы ей приобрести корову для откорма и продажи молока, и несколько баранов для продажи осенью. 

Канатбеку Абдырахманову сорок шесть лет. Жена Канатбека не работает и находится дома с младшим сынишкой, а детей у Канатбека четверо. Чтобы прокормить семью Канатбек занимается разведением скота и зарабатывает около трёх тысяч сомов в месяц. Он надеется получить этот кредит и купить одну корову и четырёх баранов на откорм. 

Майрамкул Саданбековой сорок восемь лет. Майрамкул продаёт молоко по семь – восемь литров в день и это ей приносит около четырёх тысяч сомов в месяц. За тридцать лет замужества Майрамкул вырастила шестерых детей. Майрамкул хочет получить этот кредит для того, чтобы купить несколько овец на откорм. 

Анарбубу Барановой пятьдесят два года. Она -  мать пятерых детей. Старший сын работает коммерсантом в г. Токмок, ещё один сын работает на стройке. А два других сына помогают отцу ухаживать за скотом. Анарбубу нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить несколько баранов для дальнейшей перепродажи.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Every day, Begaim A. wakes early in the morning in order to gather eggs and take them to the market. This business yields her about seven hundred som ($15) per month. She is the leader of this group. Begaim spent most of her life living in a rural area and involved in agriculture. After her marriage, her parents left her two cows to start her own household. Twenty-seven years have passed since then. Begaim became a mother herself and had five children. Two daughters already got married and live separately. The son (he is twenty-four) also became involved in agriculture and actively helps Begaim take care of livestock. One other son (he is fifteen years old) is in eighth grade, and the youngest son is in second grade. Begaim’s husband always takes care of the household side-by-side with Begaim and helps his wife raise the children, and, together with his son, tries to constantly increase livestock headcount. Their income does not only come from the sale of eggs, but also from sale of milk and reaches up to two thousand som ($40) per month. Daily duties do not tire Begaim at all. On the contrary, she is eager to keep more livestock and increase her family income. And life gets more expensive every day and makes it necessary to make some hard decisions and push forward. Begaim decided to request this loan because it will let her buy a cow for fattening and milk sales, and several sheep for resale in the autumn. Kanatbek A. is forty-six years old. His wife does not work and stays home with the youngest son. Kanatbek has four children. In order to support the family, he is involved in breeding livestock and earns about three thousand som per month. He hopes to obtain this loan and buy one cow and four sheep for fattening. Mayramkul S. is forty-eight. She sells seven to eight liters of milk per day and earns about four thousand som per month. Throughout the thirty years of marriage, she raised six children. Mayramkul wants to obtain this loan in order to buy several sheep for fattening. Anarbubu B. is fifty-two years old. She is a mother of five children. The oldest son works as a businessman in the city of Tokmok, and one other son works at a construction site. And two other sons help their father take care of livestock. Anarbubu needs a loan in order to buy several sheep for future resale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Ednalyne

texts.en:
Ednalyne V. is from the village of Brgy. Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 55 years old. Ednalyne is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Ednalyne owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Ednalyne has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ednalyne joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ednalyne is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ednalyne from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith J., 26, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Reynaldo J., a cook, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own food stall while also delivering meat to her neighbors.

Judith has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 19,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying different cuts of meat, like pork, poultry and beef, and vegetables and seasonings for her food stall.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying different cuts of meat, like pork, poultry and beef, and vegetables and seasonings for her food stall

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita O. is from the village of Brgy. Darubba, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 43 years old. Anita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Anita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2008, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Anita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets to raise & sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Anita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise & sell

loans.name: Yat

texts.en: Mrs. Yat Y. is a local farmer, aged 45. She is a resident of Kompong Tom, Cambodia. To earn a living, Yat Y. buys small pigs and raises them for four months before selling them. She typically makes about $2.50 a day. Yat Y. has another financial earner in her husband who is a chop-wood (firewood) seller. Her husband is always complaining he faces a problem with transportation because he has to hire animal labor to deliver his chop-wood from the forest. Yat Y. is requesting a loan to buy a couple of water buffalo for her husband to use to pick up his firewood. This loan will allow the family to reduce their business expenses.

loans.use: To buy a couple of water buffalo to use for hauling.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda P., 56, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Rogelio P., they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Yolanda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 24,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries and other products to be incorporated to her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries and other products to be incorporated to her current product inventory.

loans.name: Rosario Abajar Group

texts.en:
Rosario A., from the village of Plaridel Misamis Occidental, is the 41-year-old leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loans if their fellow group member is delinquent or defaults.

Rosario, who is married and has three school-aged children, sells seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Rosario joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan, her 11th, of 25000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital. Rosario plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida V. wants to improve the life of her eight children, ranging in age from 8 to 18, while they are still under her care. Despite the family's poverty, Aida dreams of her children graduating from college and having good careers.

For now, Aida enjoys her role managing her small vegetable-selling business and the small profit it earns to support the family's primary needs every day. Instead of looking at the negative side of being poor, Aida tries to focus her thoughts on the events in her life which she considers a blessing, including having given birth to two sets of twins, now aged 8 and 16 years old. Another is being a member of ASHI, which provides her with many opportunities that she didn’t have before, most especially the opportunity to receive loans for financing a business.

Having run her business for a few years now, Aida realizes how worthwhile it is to request a loan and grow a business. She is now seeking a much larger loan from ASHI to purchase a larger stock of fruits and vegetables for sale. This will give her and her family not only a larger source of income for food and other basic needs, but also happiness for Aida having the opportunity to use her abilities in a productive way.

loans.use: To purchase a larger volume of fruits and vegetables for selling.

loans.name: Ha

texts.en: Ha T. D. is 42 years old. She is married with four children who are going to school. She breeds pigs and poultry. Besides this, she also buys and sells scrap iron at home. She has done this job for 12 years. She has a monthly income of about 4.000.000 Vietnamese Dong. She joined SEDA, a Kiva partner, in 2009 and has repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 7.840.000 VND to buy more scrap iron.

loans.use: To buy more scrap iron

loans.name: Tamara's Group

texts.ru:
Тамара Жайлообаева, лидер группы – жительница г. Каракол. Этот город издавна славен своей необычайной красотой окружающей его природы. Туристы из многих стран приезжают сюда, чтобы насладиться чистым горным воздухом, катанием на лыжах на лыжных базах загородом, а также просто посмотреть на природу, на горные ели и величественные горы Кыргызстана. 
Тамаре пятьдесят восемь лет. Она живёт вместе с мужем, старшим сыном, невесткой и младшей дочерью. Муж Тамары – пенсионер и последние годы находится на постоянном отдыхе. Старший сын – таксист. Второй сын – студент. Он учится в одном из столичных ВУЗов. Одних заработков сына на всю семью естественно не хватает и Тамара и её муж занимаются домашним хозяйством. Они выращивают картошку и сдают молоко ежедневно по пять – шесть литров,  и это приносит им около двух тысяч сомов ежемесячно. А также Тамара продаёт яйца. Однажды Тамара с мужем повезли двадцать тонн картошки в Казахстан и удачно её реализовали. Им удалось приобрести кашар (это стойло (stall) или загон для скота, который находится у подножия гор, рядом с пастбищами). Сейчас их скот находится в кашаре. Таким образом, дома все заняты делом. Тамаре, необходима кое – какая помощь. Она нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить ГСМ на полевые работы. Нужно подготовить поле к посадке картофеля. 

Джумакул Солтоевой пятьдесят лет. Она воспитала пятерых детей. Джумакул всю жизнь старалась ради детей и до сих пор не знала отдыха. Она и сейчас работает в школе раздатчиком в буфете. Её зарплата составляет всего восемьсот тридцать сомов. Муж Джумакул занимается электро – сварочными работами, а один из сыновей занимается сельским хозяйством. Поэтому Джумакул надеется получить этот кредит и помочь сыну купить ГСМ на полевые работы.

Кенжекан Рысбековой сорок восемь лет. У Кенжекан шестеро детей. Старшей дочери двадцать семь, а самому младшему сыну одиннадцать лет. Кенжекан работает заведующим сельского ФАПа, а муж вышел на пенсию и не работает. Кенжекан надеется получить кредит, чтобы купить ГСМ и помочь сыну в полевых работах.

Жылдыз Узаковой двадцать пять лет. У Жылдыз два сына – близнецов. Муж Жылдыз работает трактористом – комбайнером, а Жылдыз ежедневно сдаёт по пять литром молока и тем самым помогает мужу кормить семью. Жылдыз обратилась за этим кредитом, с целью закупить ГСМ для весенних работ на поле. Они собираются сажать пшеницу. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Tamara J., the leader of this group, is a resident of the town of Karakol. This town has been long known for the unique beauty of its surrounding nature. Tourists from many countries come here to enjoy the clean mountain air, skiing at ski resorts and also just look at the nature, mountain trees and majestic mountains of Kyrgyzstan. Tamara is fifty-eight years old. She lives together with her husband, oldest son, daughter-in-law and youngest daughter. Tamara’s husband is retired and spent the last few years on permanent rest. The oldest one is a taxi driver. The second son is a student. He goes to one of the universities in the capital. The son’s salary is obviously not enough for the whole family, and Tamara and her husband are involved in a domestic business. They grow potatoes and milk, five to six liters, per day, and this yields them close to two thousand som per month. Also, Tamara sells eggs. Once Tamara and her husband took twenty tons of potatoes to Kazakhstan and successfully sold it.
