They were able to buy a kashar (barn for livestock located at the bottom of the mountains near a pasture). So everyone in the family stays busy. Tamara needs some help. She needs a loan in order to buy diesel fuel for field work. It is needed to prepare the field for sowing potatoes. Djumakul S. is fifty years old. She raised five children. Djumakul tried to provide for her children all her life and to this day, finds no rest. Even now, she works at a school as a server at a buffet. Her salary is only eight hundred thirty som. Djumakul’s husband is involved in electrical and welding work, and one of the sons is involved in agriculture. This is why Djumakul hopes to obtain this loan and help her son buy diesel fuel for field work. Kenjekan R. is forty-eight years old. She has six children. The oldest daughter is twenty-seven, and the youngest son is eleven years old. Kenjekan works at the village outpatient clinic, and the husband retired and does not work. She hopes to get this loan in order to buy diesel fuel and help her son with field work. Jyldyz U. is twenty-five years old. She has two twin sons. Her husband works as a tractor-combainer driver, and Jyldyz sells five liters of milk daily, which helps the husband support the family. She requested this loan in order to buy diesel fuel for spring field work. They plan to plant wheat.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of diesel fuel for field work

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz H., 41, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She has been managing a water station while also renting out some apartment rooms. These two activities make up her total income per month. She also does a little food vending while maintaining her two main businesses.

Luz has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 45,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by allowing her to pay for maintenance and repairs for her apartments. She will also pay for the needs and bills of the water station and buy groceries to replenish her current product stock.

She dreams that her businesses will continue to grow.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Maintenance and repair for her apartments, to pay for needs and bills of the water station and to buy groceries to replenish her current product stock

loans.name: Esterlita Permale Group

texts.en: Esterlita P. is from the village of Plaridel. She is 59 years old. Esterlita is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Esterlita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Esterlita runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Esterlita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Esterlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC.This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Esterlita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the third loan taken out by Esterlita from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Michelle Amomonpon Group

texts.en:
Michelle A., 26, is from the village of Western Poblacion. She is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of a group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Michelle is married and has two small children. To make a living, she runs a store selling dried goods. Michelle is just starting this business.

In 2005, Michelle joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. Michelle is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Michelle from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Tayo

texts.en:
Tayo is into the making of snacks like egg rolls, buns, fish rolls, donuts and puff-puffs. She supplies her customers after she has finished making them. Her snacks are nice and her customers patronize her a lot. She is asking for loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more flour, yeast, show glass and one popcorn machine, in order to satisfy her customers. 

34-year-old Tayo is married with one kid. Her husband is a transporter and they live in Lagos State, Nigeria. She appreciates all Kiva lenders for their financial support.  
.

loans.use: To purchase more flour, yeast, show glass and a popcorn machine

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz L. is making sure that she can meet her family's daily needs. Married to Buenvenido L., a farmer, they have five children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time.

Beatriz has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues and has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store business. To ensure the success of her business, Beatriz would like to apply for a PHP 19,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries and other goods needed to replenish her stock. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education until they are able to successfully provide for themselves.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries and other items needed to replenish her stock.

loans.name: Generosa

texts.en: Generosa runs a small store located at her house. She is 67 years old and has three children. She sells fruits, bread and many other items. She hopes that her store will grow so that she can help improve her family’s living conditions. She also works hard for her children who still go to school. She wants them to finish college and have a bright future. Generosa applied for a loan of Php13, 000, which she will use to buy supplies for her store. This loan will help her achieve her goals in life.

loans.use: Additional inventory

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda is a 44-year-old married woman with a one-year-old child. She sells fresh fish in her her neighborhood. She is also an electronic load dealer selling pre-paid cellphone units. Consumption of cellphone loads in her town is growing fast which is why she invested in it. She plans to buy a new cellphone that she could use for loading. She applied for a loan of Php30, 000. She will use it to buy fish and hopefully a cellphone.

loans.use: Fish and a cellular phone

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita E., 52, is making sure that her family's daily needs are met. Married to Julio E., a carpenter, they have four children. Nenita has a variety store to help with the family's income and chance for a better life. 

Nenita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues and uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store. To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 25,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish her inventory. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a good, comfortable life for her children.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries needed to replenish inventory

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina s 53 years old, single and has a 23-year-old child. To make a living, she bakes cupcakes, polvoron (a type of shortbread), and other delicacies that she sells in her community. She hopes to prosper in what she does and wants to improve her family’s living conditions. She joined CEVI and asked for a loan of Php13, 000 that she will use to buy flour, sugar and other baking needs.

loans.use: Flour, sugar and other baking needs

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M., 36, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Mauro M., an overseas Filipino worker who works as a welder, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Erlinda M. has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 10,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy groceries needed to replenish stock in her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries needed to replenish stock in her variety store

loans.name: Leonides

texts.en:
Leonides is a dressmaker. She is 43 years old and married with three children. Her oldest child is 18 and in college. She says that her business is really helpful to her family, especially for her children’s education. She hopes to have her own shop someday.

Leonides would like to request a loan of 16,000 Philippine pesos. She will use it to buy cloth, thread and other materials she needs for her dressmaking business.

loans.use: Cloth, thread and other materials

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna T., 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well for the sake of her child and so that her family can have a better life. She manages her own variety store while renting out some rooms, which enables her to further augment her meager income.

Myrna has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 10,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used to buy much needed stock to replenish her product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a good and comfortable living environment for her child.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy much needed stock to replenish her product inventory

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn R., 34, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Elmer R., a sales marketer, she is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling her own handmade sandals for quite some time now.

Roselyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her sandals business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 18,000 Philippine pesos loan. This amount will be used to buy equipment and raw materials needed to further maintain production of her sandals.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide good living conditions for her family.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment and raw materials needed to further maintain production of her sandals

loans.name: Laura

texts.en: Laura is a 42 year-old woman who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with her husband and their four children. Laura has a grocery store selling candies, canned food, beverages, chips, biscuits etc. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to expand and diversify her merchandise according to her customers' needs. This is her third loan cycle and she has always paid on time. Laura decided to start her business because she wanted to supplement her husband’s income, and also because she likes trading. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. She plans to keep on improving and expanding her store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Gliceria

texts.en:
Gliceria G., 58, makes sure that her family's daily needs are met. Married to Policarpio G., a variety store owner, she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She also manages her own general merchandise store which sells clothing and other goods.

Gliceria has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 25,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital and to add more inventory to her expanding business.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and a deep freezer

loans.name: Zaynab

texts.en: Zaynab is an 18 year-old woman who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. Zaynab owns a souvenir/gift shop selling teddy bears, and girls’ accessories like necklaces, bracelets, and earrings. She also sells home-decoration items like frames, vases, artificial flowers and lots more. She decided on opening her shop because she has selling skills and knows how to meet her clients' demand. With the loan, she plans to purchase merchandise. This is her second loan cycle having repaid a previous loan on time. She plans to keep on improving and diversifying her merchandise so that she can attract more customers.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Loi

texts.en: Loi T. N. is forty-five years old. She lives in Phu Man Village, Cho Town, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh with her husband and two children. She has a store at home. She sells plastic products (including plastic pots, plastic chairs, and plastic baskets). Her children are in school. Her husband works near the house. They have a monthly income of about 5,300,000 VND. Loi joined SEDA in 2008. Since joining, she has been punctual in repaying her loans. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 7,840,000 VND to invest in her store. She hopes her investment will turn a profit so that her family will be able to afford to buy more household appliances.

loans.use: To invest in her store

loans.name: Salwa

texts.en: Salwa is a thirty-nine-year-old woman who lives in Saida, which is in southern Lebanon, with her four children. Salwa owns a shop that sells clothing for babies and children. She also sells accessories for babies like baby bottles, towels, bibs, and toys. She decided to open her shop because she gained experience in sales and always wanted to own a shop for her own. She requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise; especially now that summer is coming, she needs to buy clothing to match the new season. This is the first time Salwa has requested a loan. When she first started her business, she had some difficulty diversifying her merchandise. For the future, she plans to keep on improving her loan.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is a forty-seven-year-old woman who lives in Saida, which is in southern Lebanon, with her husband and their three children. Lina has owned a grocery store since 2002. She carries all types of canned food, pasta, home cleaning products, beverages, and more. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. Lina has been a microcredit client for seven years, and she has always paid on time. 
Lina is special in her business because she knows how to treat her clients; she also has a good reputation. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have a lot of merchandise. She decided to begin her business to supplement her husband’s income and because she always wanted to open a shop for herself. In the future, she plans to expand her work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Souher

texts.en:
Souher is a forty-nine-year-old woman who lives in Saida, which is in southern Lebanon, with her husband. Souher has been working as a seamstress since 1996. She repairs and sews all types of clothes; she also does curtains, bed sheets, and more. She requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a sewing machine and thread for her work. This is her fourth cycle and she has always paid on time.

Souher's work is speciA.; she is known for her good and precise work. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties since she already had sewing machines. She learned the business when she was young, so she has always been sewing. She plans to continue improving in her work in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and thread for her work.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en: Zeinab is a forty-six-year-old woman who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon. She is the mother of three children. Zeinab has been selling fishing equipment for five years, including fishing nets, fishing rods, fishing feeds, and more. This is the first time that she has requested a loan. She hopes to use the loan to purchase merchandise for her fishing shop since now it is a good season to fish. Some of her family members have been working as fishers, that is how she decided to open her shop. She also wanted to have independent work in order to improve her family’s income. For the future, she plans to improve her work and to keep attracting more clients thanks to her competitive prices.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her fishing shop.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario B., 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Matias B., a mason, they are blessed with seven children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Rosario has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, she is now applying for a PHP 12,000 loan as additional capital to buy groceries to replenish stocks and continue the operation of her variety store. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners meeting weekly to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to replenish stocks and continue operations of her variety store.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is a forty-seven-year-old mother of three children. She has been living in Bourj el Barajneh, which is in the southern suburbs of Lebanon. Fatima has been selling saj bread for twelve years. A saj is the metal oven used to make saj bread; it is a traditional Lebanese cooking dome. The saj is used to make several types of bread, including markouk (thinned) bread and doughy confections, or mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza; the most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it any time of the day, but it somehow tastes better in the morning. For the first time, Fatima has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw material for her saj, as well as to purchase a refrigerator for her work. Fatima is very well known in her region for her good and tasty saj. She is also a good cook in general, but she decided to focus on the saj because it is demanding. When she first started her business, she wanted to improve her family’s income, but now that she has been working, she is glad that she has independent work. For the future, she plans to keep on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her saj and a refrigerator for her business.

loans.name: Maha

texts.en: Maha, 42, is a divorced mother of three children who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, the southern suburbs of Lebanon. She has owned a grocery store for almost two years selling canned food, chips, candies, beverages, and more. Maha started her business in order to improve her family’s financiA. situation and also because she wanted to have independent work. Since her divorce, she had to depend on herself and is glad to be able to do so. She has requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise to expand her stock. This is the first time that she has requested a loan. She plans to keep on improving her store and her financiA. situation.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Thuan

texts.en: Thuan T. N., 39, lives in Phu Man village, Cho Town, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She is married with three children who go to school. She breeds pigs and also has a small shop at home that serves breakfast. She has done this work for 11 years and has a monthly income of about 3.800.000 VND. She joined SEDA in 2007 and has repaid her loans punctually. She wants to borrow 7.840.000 (or 400 USD) to expand her shop.

loans.use: to expand her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more slippers and clothes to sell

loans.name: Chuyen

texts.en: Chuyen, 28, lives in Phu Man village, Cho Town, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She is married with three children and has a store that sells beef in the market. Her husband is a carpenter who makes wooden furniture — chairs, beds, etc. Together they have a monthly income of about 3.700.000 VND. She joined SEDA in 2008 with a loan of 2.000.000 VND and repaid punctually. This time, she wants to borrow 7.840.000 VND (or 400 USD) to buy wood and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy wood and expand her business.

loans.name: Elvis

texts.en:
Elvis T., 35, and his wife Irene have three children. He makes sure that he provides well so that the family can have a better life. He manages a mini grocery and also sells school supplies.

Elvis has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  He uses the money he borrows to expand and improve his businesses.

Now, with your help, he would like to apply for a Php 40,000 loan. This will be used as added capital for his expanding business by buying products needed to replenish and sustain his inventory. He dreams that his business will continue to grow so that he can provide for his children’s education until they finish their degrees. 


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying products needed to replenish and sustain his inventory

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Madame Awa D.est mariée  et mère de 7 enfants (4garçons et 3 filles). Elle est née vers 1956 à Komorow dans la préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Elle vit dans la maison de son défunt mari avec ses enfants à Loulouni ville.
Elle est matrone de son état et fait le commerce d’articles divers (pagnes, charbon de bois, bois de chauffe, parures, savons etc)  depuis  5 ans. Expérimentée grâce aux années passées dans les activités commerciales, elle les mène aujourd’hui avec réussite. 
Elle est à sa première  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et entend maintenir cette collaboration pour satisfaire ses nombreux clients dont les demandes ne cessent d’augmenter.  
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt, 50 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne dans villages avoisinants Loulouni et  vend  en gros et en détail (au comptant ou à crédit) à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 18.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter le fonds de commerce. 
Elle ambitionne d’être une grossiste et d’avoir un grand magasin de vente de pagnes wax Loulouni.
texts.en:
Mrs. Awa D.is married and the mother of seven children (four boys and three girls). She was born around 1956 in Komorow in the Kadiolo Prefecture, part of the 3rd administrative region of Mali. She lives with her children in the home of her deceased husband, in the town of Loulouni. As a matron she has been retailing various goods for the past five years: pagnes (colorful West African cloth), charcoal, firewood, adornments, soap, etc. She is successful today in her commercial activities thanks to her past experience. This is her first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, and she intends to maintain the relationship to satisfy her numerous customers whose requests are steadily increasing. With her loan she will buy 50 cartloads of firewood. She gets her supplies from villages in the vicinity of Loulouni and sells wholesale and retail (for cash or credit) to a customer base of both men and women. She expects to reach a monthly income of 18,000 FCFA which for the most part will be used to increase her working capital. Her ambition is to become a wholesaler and to own a large store selling pagnes wax (a popular type of pagnes) in Loulouni.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy firewood

loans.name: Ovilla

texts.en:
Ovilla G., 34, makes sure that her family's daily needs are met. She and her husband, Isagani G., a driver, have seven children. She helps the family income by managing a barbecue stall and also operates a jeepney or small bus.

Ovilla, or Beck-Beck, as she is fondly called, has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her barbeque business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying raw ingredients needed such as fuel, condiments, and seasonings. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can renovate her house to incorporate her own barbecue stall right in front of it.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying goods she needs (like fuel, condiments and seasonings) for her barbecue business.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa T. N. is 35 years old and lives in Phu Man village. She is married with three children who go to school. She is a farmer. Also, every day, she goes to other villages in the region to buy scrap iron to resell. She has done this for 6 years and makes about 80.000 VND per day. She joined SEDA in 2009 and repaid her loans punctually. She feels happy because she can save a little money. Now she would like to borrow 7.840.000 VND more (or 400 USD) to buy scrap iron.

loans.use: to buy scrap – iron.

loans.name: Bibata

texts.fr:
Madame Bibata S. est mariée mère de 1 enfant (1 fille). Elle est née le 30 Septembre 1981 à Kaï, une commune rurale de la sous préfecture de Loulouni, préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec son époux et leurs enfants à Kaï.
Elle est aide soignante à Kaï et fait le commerce de céréales depuis 5 ans. Avec son expérience dans le commerce de céréales, elle le mène aujourd’hui avec réussite. 
Elle est à sa première  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et compte maintenir cette collaboration pour satisfaire ses nombreux clients dont les demandes ne cessent d’augmenter.  
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt, 2 tonnes de maïs. Elle s’approvisionne à Kaï et environnants, aussi au marché de Loulouni les jours de foire. Elle vend  en gros et en détail (au comptant ou à crédit) à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60.000FCFA qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter le fonds de commerce. 
Elle ambitionne d’être une grossiste en ayant  un grand magasin de stockage.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bibata S. is married and the mother of one child (a girl). She was born 30 September 1981 in Kaï, a rural community in the Loulouni sub-prefecture, part of the Kadiolo Prefecture, in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. She lives in a monogamous family with her husband and her child in Kaï. She is a nurse’s aide in Kaï and has also retailed grain cereals for the past five years. Her past experience in the trading of grain cereals ensures her current success in this activity. This is her first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, and she intends to maintain the relationhip to satisfy her numerous customers whose requests are steadily increasing. With her loan she will buy two tons of corn. She gets her supplies from Kaï and the surrounding area, and also from the Loulouni market on market fair days. She sells wholesale and retail (cash or credit) to both men and women customers. She expects to reach a monthly income of 60,000 FCFA which for the most part will be used to increase her working capital. Her ambition is to become a wholesaler and own a large warehouse.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain cereals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more kerosene

loans.name: Reiner

texts.en:
Reiner M., 57, is making sure that his family has enough provisions for their daily needs. He is married to Emma M. and they are blessed with three children. He makes sure that he provides well so that their family can have a better life. He has been managing their personal pharmacy and rice stall for quite some time now.

Reiner has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. He is consistent in paying his dues because he used the money he borrowed to expand and improve his pharmacy and rice stall.

To ensure the success of his business, he would like to apply for a 22,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used to buy more stock for both the pharmacy and the rice stall.

He dreams that his business will continue to grow and thus enable him to achieve his dreams for his family and his community.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Buying more stock for both the pharmacy and the rice stall

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boubacar C. est marié à une femme et est père de 2 enfants (1garçon et 1 fille). Il est né vers 1975 dans la sous préfecture de Loulouni, préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Il vit dans une famille monogame avec son épouse et leurs enfants à Kaï.
N’ayant pas fait l’école très tôt il s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment les activités de boucher et de rôtisseur de petits ruminants et de bœufs depuis  maintenant 15 ans. 
Dans la matinée, c’est la vente de la viande crue et dans l’après midi c’est l’activité de rôtisseur qui commence jusqu’à des heures tardives dans la nuit. Expérimenté en raison des années d’activités, il le fait avec réussite. 
Il est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt passé a été bien remboursé. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 1boeuf et 7 petits ruminants. Il s’approvisionne à Loulouni ville  et environnants. Il vend au comptant et souvent à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 105.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Sikasso ville.
texts.en:
Mr. Boubacar C. is married and the father of two children (a boy and a girl). He was born around 1975 in the Loulouni sub-prefecture, part of the Kadiolo Prefecture, in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. He lives in a monogamous family with his wife and children in Kaï. Not having attended school, he was attracted from an early age by revenue-generating activities, and for the past 15 years has been a butcher and roaster of small ruminants and beef. The mornings are devoted to the sale of fresh meat, and the roasting activity begins in the afternoon until late at night. He succeeds well in his business, thanks to his years of experience. This is his second collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, the first having been fully reimbursed. With his loan he will buy one ox and seven small ruminants. He gets his supplies from Loulouni and the surrounding area. He sells for cash and often on credit (wholesale and retail) to both men and women customers. He expects an average monthly income of 105,000 FCFA of which part will be used to increase his working capital. The remainder will be put into savings as his ambition is to build a home in the town of Sikasso.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy oxen and small ruminants

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida L., 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Salvador L., a retiree, and they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own fish stall for quite some time.

Zenaida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her fish business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 14,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used to buy more quantities and species of fish to increase her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can branch out and try new businesses. She also envisions a car for her and her family.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities and species of fish to increase her current product inventory

loans.name: Airene

texts.en:
Airene A., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Sergio A., a construction worker, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own direct-selling business while also making and selling homemade delicacies.

Airene has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 18,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used to buy more quantities of products that she can sell.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of products that she can sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr:
Madame Maïmouna D.est mariée et mère de 4 enfants (1garçon et 3filles). Elle est née vers 1977 à Manankoro dans la préfecture de Bougouni, 3eme Région administrative du Mali.  Elle vit avec son mari avec leurs enfants à Kadiolo quartier Koko.
Elle fait le commerce d’articles divers (essence, savons traditionnels, préparation et vente d’encens) il y a plus de 6 ans ans. L’activité dominante chez Maïmouna est la vente de l’essence et  elle se fait aider de temps à autres pour les besoins de la circonstance par son mari. Elle mène son activité avec beaucoup de réussite.
Elle est à sa sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt, 1000 litres d’essence. Elle s’approvisionne en République de la Côte d’Ivoire  qui est un pays frontalier du Mali et précisément à Tomikoro auprès des demi grossistes. Elle vend au comptant, souvent à crédit (sur commande) et en détail à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 145.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie pour aider  son mari à gérer les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maimouna D.is married and the mother of four children (one boy and three girls). She was born around 1977 in Manankoro, in the Bougouni prefecture, the third administrative region of Mali. She lives with her husband and children in the town of Kadiolo, Koko district. Her business is selling various articles (gasoline, traditional soaps, preparing and selling incense), which she has been doing for six years now. Her main activity is selling gasoline, and as the need arises, her husband also aides her. Her business has been going very well. This is her sixth collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yriwaso, and all previous loans have been duly reimbursed. With this loan, she plans to purchase 1,000 liters (about 264 gallons) of gasoline. She buys her stock in Côte d’Ivoire, a country neighboring with Mali, more precisely in Tomikoro, from mid-size wholesale distributors. She sells retail, for cash, often in credit (upon request) to a customer based composed of both women and men. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly income of 145,000 West African Francs, a part of which will be used to bolster her business capital and the other part will help her husband with the everyday family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing gasoline (for resale)

loans.name: Mariame

texts.fr:
Madame  Mariame Koné est une veuve et mère de 8 enfants qui est née le 18 Avril 1957 à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Elle vit dans la maison de son défunt mari avec ses  enfants à Loulouni ville.
Matrone de son état au Centre de Santé Communautaire de Loulouni, elle mène également des activités de commerce de bois de chauffe, d’ustensiles de cuisines, de tasses etc depuis plusieurs années. Expérimentée et très sollicitée, elle s’est procurée d’un âne et d’une charrette et  loue le service d’un charretier pour assurer le transport et la livraison de son bois de chauffe. 
Elle parvient à concilier les deux activités (de matrone et de commerce) avec beaucoup de réussite.
Elle est à son quatorzième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Tous les treize prêts précédents  ont été remboursés correctement. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt,  5 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe par semaine, 5 pièces de pagnes wax, 3 douzaines de tasses en plastique et 2 douzaines d’ustensiles de cuisine. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente dans les villages avoisinants  Loulouni, au comptant, à  crédit, en gros et en détail, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 140.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne afin de pouvoir terminer sa construction.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariame Koné is a widow and the mother of eight children. She was born 18 April 1957 in Bamako (capital of Mali), and lives in the home of her deceased husband with her children, in the town of Loulouni. She is a matron in the Community Health Centre of Loulouni, and for several years has also traded in firewood, kitchen utensils, cups, etc. Quite experienced and much in demand, she bought a donkey and a cart, and rents the services of a cart driver to ensure transport and delivery of the firewood. She manages to reconcile both activities (matron and trader) with great success. This is her 14th loan with Soro Yiriwaso MFI, all previous 13 loans having been fully reimbursed. With this loan she intends to buy: five cartloads of firewood per week, five lengths of pagnes wax (pagnes: colourful West African cloth), three dozen plastic cups, and two dozen kitchen utensils. Her supplies come from wholesalers and she resells her goods in neighbouring villages, for cash or credit, wholesale and retail, to both men and women customers. She hopes to reach a monthly income of 140,000 FCFA, of which part will serve to reinforce her working capital, and the remainder will be put into savings towards the completion of her house.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann F., 44, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Rodrigo F., a driver, and they are blessed with four children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing their own canteen while overseeing the operation of their jeepney.

Mary Ann has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation(CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, she has applied for a 34,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses to buy spare parts for the maintenance of the jeepney and some stock for the canteen. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for the maintenance of two operating jeepneys

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua K. produces palm oil locally for sale at Jukwa.To prepare her palm oil, she gets palm nuts from farmers on the farm. She washes them, boils them for a while until they become soft and tender. She scoops the cooked fruits into a big mortar and gently pounds with a pestle to avoid damaging the nut. Water is then added to the pounded fruit. The mixture of water and the pounded fruit is squeezed and filtered to get the juice out and the chaff removed. (The chaff is sometimes used by the local people to light charcoal fires).The juice is boiled again and as it boils the fresh oil will be seen floating on the surface of the pot; it is scooped into yet another pot and left to cool. Fresh oil from palm fruits is traditionally used in eating roasted yam or plantain in Africa – especially on the farms after a hard day's work.

Efua has received junior high education. She is a widow and has four children. Efua has been selling palm oil for some time now. She is responsible for the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more palm fruits to make palm oil for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save up for her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy more palm fruits to make palm oil for sale

loans.name: Seydina Hamiza

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydina Hamiza Koné est marié à une femme, père de 2 enfants,il est né vers 1976  dans la préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Il vit à Loulouni dans une famille monogame.
Il fait le commerçant depuis 5 ans et a comme créneau l’achat vente des habits prêt à porter. Il mène son commerce avec assez de réussite compte tenue de son expérience à la matière.
Il est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt passé a été bien remboursé et Seydina souhaite maintenir cette relation afin de mieux  satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 15 douzaines de prêt à porter pour les jeunes hommes et 30 douzaines pour les enfants. Il s’approvisionne au grand marché de  Sikasso ville et au marché de Bamako. Il vend au comptant et souvent à crédit, en détail à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 90.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne construire une maison à usage à Kadiolo ville.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydina Hamiza Koné is married and the father of two children.  He was born around 1976 in Kadiolo Prefecture, 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Seydina lives in Loulouni in a monogamous family.  He has been a merchant for five years, and his niche is in buying and selling read-to-wear clothing.  His business has been fairly successful, given his experience in it. Seydina is on his second collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  The past loan was repaid, and he wishes to maintain this relationship in order to satisfy further his burgeoning customers base.  He intends to use his loan to buy 15 dozen pieces of ready-to-wear clothing for young men and 30 dozen for children.  He gets his supplies at the grand market of Sikasso Ccity and at the Bamako market.  He accepts cash and often credit for retail sales made to a customer base composed of women and men.  He envisions making a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be use to increase his working capital, and the other portion will be put into savings, since his ambition is to build a house in Kadiolo City.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For buying ready-to-wear clothing to sell

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius B. is a hardworking man, vibrant sounding in terms of business and agriculture enterprises. He deals in poultry farming, cattle keeping with a banana plantation, all of which generates income for his family.

Julius’ main drawback has been cattle diseases and pests that attack his cattle and plantations and which have reduced his yields. Therefore this loan is to help him buy more farm tools like pesticides, drugs for deworming cattle, and mulches for the plantation. This will help him improve his yields in terms of milk, eggs and bananas, thus enabling him to meet his customers’ high demand.

This will increase Julius’ sales revenue, hence making him more able to meet his family’s requirements in terms of tuition fees for his children, and other needs and enable him to live a more self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To buy farm tools such as fertilizer, pesticides and mulch

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more hair extension to sell

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda S., 56, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Domingo S., an Overseas Filipino Worker based in Qatar, and they are blessed with two children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own hog-raising business while operating a jeepney and a variety store.

Yolanda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, she has applied for a 20,000  Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy a few piglets for the hog business and groceries for the variety store. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy a few piglets for a hog business and groceries for a variety store

loans.name: Nana Adjoa

texts.en:
Nana Adjoa F. is divorced and lives with her two children. She has been through senior high school. Nana Adjoa is into palm oil production at Jukwa. She uses the earnings she makes from the sale of palm oil for the general upkeep of her home. Nana Adjoa will use this loan to purchase more palm fruits to make palm oil for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana Adjoa plans to save to buy a palm nut peeling machine.
 
To prepare her locally made palm oil, she gets his palm nuts from the farmers on the farm.
She washes them, boils it for about forty minutes until it becomes soft and tender. The cooked fruits are strained and put into a big mortar and gently squeezed with a pestle avoiding damaging the nut but only to peel the pulp covering the nut. Water is then added to it, the juice obtained is strained separating the nut and taking out the chaff with the hand. (The chaff is sometimes used by the local people to light charcoal fire).The juice is boiled again and as it boils, the fresh oil will be seen floating whilst the water keeps boiling beneath. The scooped oil is left to cool and later bottled or preserved for sale.
Fresh oil form palm fruits are traditionally used in eating roasted yam or plantain in Africa especially in the farms after a hard days work.

loans.use: To purchase more palm fruits to make palm oil for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To stock more cattle to match his customers' high demand

loans.name: Shittu

texts.en: Shittu, residing with her family in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria, is very hardworking and makes sure that she has food on the table everyday through her work selling clothing and school cardigans. In this business for over 15 years, she sells to many schools.  Shittu is 33 years old, married, and has two children, both doing well in school. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to help her make the business more profitable and provide benefits for her children. She thanks you for your support

loans.use: To purchase more materials for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more drinks and snacks  to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and rechargeable phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a hard-working businesswoman who sells a variety of brand new clothes to customers. She is single and business-oriented. She is thirty-six years old and the mother of two children. She spends most of her time taking care of her business and supporting her children in school. She loves selling and enjoys serving customers. 

Josephine trades in brand new clothes ranging from jeans, skirts and tops to straight dresses for all ages and both sexes. She has operated this trade for the past two years in the central market of Kumasi. Josephine believes in customer care and her broad smile almost always draws customers to her shop, making her one of the most successful traders in this product line. She deposits money with suppliers in the capital city to be supplied with stock almost every month to enable her to cut down on frequent travels to keep up with demand. She hopes to receive the loan to purchase more stock to serve her customers. 

Josephine is optimistic about the future and she hopes to acquire another store and open a branch in a different market in order to make more money to better support her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothes - jeans, skirts, straight dresses, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more palm oil and ground-nut oil to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks and pepper soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine works hard as a family man. His sense of duty and diligence make him a successful businessman. He is a husband and father of four children who are pursuing education at different levels. He is a manufacturer of a local ointment. He combines herbs and plant materials to prepare the ointment which provides a cure to many skin diseases and release of bodily pains. He has operated this business for the past five years. He has a large number of customers due to the effectiveness of his ointment. He prepares the ointment and supplies it to pharmaceutical shops. 

He dreams of converting his ointment enterprise into an herbal clinic to provide a wide range of herbal cures to people with skin problems. He plans to use the loan to purchase herbs and chemicals to prepare his ointment in bulk. He desires to save more money to support all his children through university education.

loans.use: To purchase herbs, plant materials and chemicals

loans.name: Afusat

texts.en:
Afusat is 38 years old, married with 4 children; they all live in Ibadan town in Oyo State, Nigeria. She sells medicine; she has been in this business for over 8 years and with LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. 

Afusat is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. 

Afusat would like to get a loan to purchase additional medicine and re-supply her inventory. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support of her business.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks in crates and frozen food to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase needed equipment and improve his vehicle-repair workshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Asi

texts.en: Asi B. sells locally produced salt and soap at Jukwa. Asi has a senior high school educational background. She is married and lives with her four children. Her husband is a blacksmith. She helps her husband in providing food, clothing and shelter for the family. Her loan will be used to buy more salt and soap to sell. She hopes to save the new income from her business to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more salt and soap to sell

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa S. sells a variety of biscuits at Jukwa market. Adwoa has not received any form of education. She is a widow blessed with two children. She is responsible for the welfare of the home. Her loan will serve as additional income to be added to her business income to buy more provisions and biscuits to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her expanded business to save to build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and biscuits to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: R.c. Primary School, Mathan Village Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers of the R.C Primary School, Mathan village, near Magburaka town in Northern Sierra Leone. This school was established in 1962. School staff from this institution, like many other schools’ staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Fifty-year-old James F. C. is the leader of this group of teachers. Mr. C., who has been in the teaching profession for 45 years now, was born in Mayatha village. He is married and has eighteen children. With his share of the loan, James will buy house-building materials like cement and sand.

(Attached to this photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy house-building materials like cement and sand

loans.name: Sa Ben Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Sa Ben group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-scale businesswomen who have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group in order to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, they will be able to buy more goods to add to their stock, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

Kadiatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kadiatu K. was born in Magburaka town 30 ago. She is married to a businessman and they have five children. Three of her children are in secondary school, one in primary school and the last is not of school-going age. Kadiatu has been a businesswoman for many years now. She sells jewelry, toiletries and cosmetics. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items in wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy jewelry, toiletries and cosmetics

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa G. cooks rice with tomato sauce and spaghetti to sell at Jukwa. Yaa has received a junior high education.  She is married and stays with her five dependents. Her husband is a farmer. Yaa has been cooking rice to sell for some time now. She helps her husband take care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more raw rice and other ingredients to cook and sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to reinvest into her business. This picture was taken in one of the market shades where she was selling.

loans.use: To buy more raw rice and other ingredients

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 39 years old, married, and has four children. She lives with her family in Lagos State.
Sarah sells bricks and has been in this trade for many years. She also has a business selling drinks. She is requesting a loan of 140,000 NGN to buy cement in bulk for brick-making. Sarah says this will reduce cost price and her transport costs to market, and increase her profit. It will also assist her to serve her customers better and this, in turn, will help her in caring for her family's needs. Sarah says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cement for brick-making

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more catering materials

loans.name: Help We Group

texts.en:
Here are small-scale businesswomen from the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They named their group “Help We” and chose Jeneba S. (who is pictured second from right) as their leader. They are applying for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each in the group in order to further expand their businesses.

30-year-old Jeneba was born in Kono, eastern Sierra Leone. She is married and has four children: two in secondary school and two in primary school. Jeneba sells market-food such as magi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, sugar, etc. She has been running this business for five years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy magi, salt, and sugar at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy magi, salt, sugar at wholesale

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is very smart and prides herself on her patience and strong customer relations. She is 50 years old and runs a book shop. She has been operating her book shop for ten years and is eager to be taking out this loan. She plans to use this loan to purchase a variety of reading and writing books and stationery to serve her customers. Cecilia’s shop is strategically located near both offices and schools. This enables her to sell her books and stationery to her target market. She hopes the extra profits she will generate will enable her to expand into a bigger book shop. 

Cecilia is married to an artisan. Together they have four children, ranging in age from 12 – 20 years. Their common dream is to be financially self-sustaining and to be able to support their children through quality education.

loans.use: To purchase assorted reading and writing books

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more children's clothes to sell

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammad is the father of a nine-year-old daughter and a six-year-old son.

Mohamamd is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority but his salary barely covers basic family needs. Therefore he is thinking of a job which he can do after work hours that will help him afford living expenses, especially that his daughter is having health problems which requires regular hospital visits.

Mohammad came to FATEN to take a loan in order to purchase a three-wheeled carriage to sell candies, beverages, sweets and snacks. He will start selling these items in Ramallah bus station which usually has a huge number of potential customers.

Mohammad hopes with this income to improve his family’s living conditions and be able to provide his daughter with the proper treatment she needs.

loans.use: To purchase a cart for his new retail business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Dieu Vivant Plus Group

texts.en:
Jules P. is the manager of the group “Dieu Vivant Plus,” which means “Living God” in French. The group is made up of 28 members, firmly united to receive loans through the micro-finance institution HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses.

Jules is 47 years old and a father of seven children whose ages vary between 3 and 15. He also cares for a brother-in-law. Jules sells beverages to the west of Kinshasa. He has been in business since 2005. Jules joined one of HOPE’s groups (a DRCongo microfinance program) in 2009 and received 5 loans, all of which he has paid back regularly. He has worked hard to develop his business. With the high demand of his clients, Jules intends to use this next loan to buy 10 crates of drinks for resale at a profit, as well as some goods in bulk for his general store to increase his income. He hopes to generate more profit to support his family. Currently, his business generates $90 in profit per week. Jules’s ambition is to open a beverage facility and deliver beverages in his area.

loans.use: purchasing 10 crates of drinks and goods in bulk

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en: Habiba A. sells slippers in a pan moving from one house to the other in and around Jukwa. Habiba has acquired a senior high education.  She is married and has three children. She assists her husband in taking care of the entire family. Her loan will be used to buy more slippers for sale. She hopes to use the new earnings she gets from her business to save to buy a shop. The picture is of A. getting ready to start her normal routine of moving from house to house with her slippers.

loans.use: To buy more slippers for sale.

loans.name: Ama Dorcas

texts.en: Ama Dorcas B. went to a commercial school where she learned how to make various pastries using flour. She is married and lives with her three wonderful children.  Ama Dorcas makes pastries to sell at Jukwa. She has been in this business for about two years now. Her husband is a kente weaver. Ama Dorcas provides help to the husband by paying school fees and utility bills. She will use the loan she is going to receive to purchase more flour, sugar and other ingredients to prepare a variety of pastries to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama Dorcas plans to save to buy a bigger oven.

loans.use: To purchase more flour, sugar and other ingredients

loans.name: James K.

texts.en:
James is a 30 years old gentleman, who is married to Sheilah. They have two children, ages five and two. He was introduced to KADET by an existing client and is happy to have joined.

With this first loan, James intends to buy maize seeds, bean seeds, and fertilizers.  Apart from maize farming, James also has a tea plantation from which he earns additional income.

He hopes to buy a plot in the town of Kapsabet and build rental houses in order to earn more income, which he will then invest in modern farming equipment to increase his farm production.

loans.use: To purchase seeds to plant, and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Maintenence and repair of his vehicle

loans.name: Simion K

texts.en:
Simion is a 54-year-old gentleman. He is married and blessed with three children who all go to school. With this fourth loan, Simion intends to purchase maize seeds, phosphate and beans to plant. He will also use it to pay for ploughing, planting and weeding expenses.

Besides farming, Simion also runs a pool table and a photocopy business that give him additional income. His plan for the future is to buy more land for farming, and to ensure that all his children get a good education.

loans.use: To buy maize seeds and phosphate, and pay for labour

loans.name: Hellen J

texts.en:
Hellen is a 36-year-old woman, married and blessed with four children aged 15, 12, 9 and 6 years, respectively. She was introduced to KADET by an existing client. With this first loan, she intends to plow more land and plant more than the previous year, hence more yield. She also has a tea farm from which she earns additional income.

Her future plans are to plant more tea and buy dairy cows from which she will get more income to educate all her children and build a better house.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Auntie

texts.en: Auntie E. is a widow and is currently staying with her two children. She has no formal educational background.  Auntie cooks rice with tomato sauce for sale at Jukwa.  Auntie uses her income to feed and educate her two children. Auntie will add the loan she is hoping to receive to her original income to purchase more rice and other ingredients to cook and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Auntie plans to build a kiosk and employ other people to also sell at various places for her.

loans.use: To purchase more rice and other ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Ronke

texts.en:
Ronke is 48 years old, married and has three children. She is a member of LAPO and has been borrowing from LAPO for the past four years. 

Ronke makes and sells bible covers and bags used for parties. She has been in this business for the past 14 years and also sells foodstuffs. She is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. 

Ronke is requesting a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to buy materials used in bag making in bulk as this will enable her get a better discount and more profit on each sale. She promises to pay back promptly and says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase materials for bag making

loans.name: Jonah K.

texts.en:
Jonah is 39 years old, married and has four children who all go to a nearby school. He has been farming for the last 18 years now and counts himself lucky to have been introduced to KADET where he can access loans.

With this first loan, he intends to buy seeds to plant on his farm and to buy more tea seedlings to increase his tea farm.  He hopes to increase his tea production in order to earn more income.

His future plan is to invest in modern farming to get more income to educate all four children and build a better house.

loans.use: To buy seeds for planting and increase the tea bush

loans.name: Julio

texts.es:
Julio es un padre de familia de 30 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a sus menores hijos en el sector Trapiche, una zona rural del distrito de Olmos, en la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a dos horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar en labores agrícolas desde hace mas de siete años, empezó trabajando como peón agrícola y con mucho esfuerzo pudo adquirir un pequeño terreno de cultivo donde siembra todo tipo de cerales y granos. Actualmente tiene instalado en su terreno un cultivo de frijol bayo, una variedad del frijol muy estimada en la zona y que tiene mucha acogida en el mercado. Este cultivo le brindará importantes ingresos para sacar adelante a su familia por lo que el trata de dar lo mejor de si para sacarlo adelante.

El cultivo ya tiene quince dias de instalado y necesita de fertilizantes y riegos para que su producción sea óptima, por este motivo Julio se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar para brindarle mantenimiento a su cultivo.

Julio es un padre trabajador y que dia a dia da lo mejor de si para sacar adelante a su familia, su mayor anhelo es poder darle a sus hijos una mejor educación y mejorar su calidad de vida. En su comunidad el es muy estimado y sus vecinos lo consideran una persona de confianza.
texts.en:
Julio, 30, lives with his wife and children in Trapiche, a rural district of Olmos, Lambayeque province, located two hours from the city of Chiclayo. He has been a farmer for over 7 years starting as a hired field hand. Through much effort he managed to acquire his own small field where he grows a variety of cereals and grains. He currently grows bayo (a type of pinto) beans which are highly sought-after in the area and welcomed in the marketplace. This crop provides an important source of income for him to support his family so he does his best to have a successful harvest. He planted two weeks ago so fertilizers and irrigation are now needed so that crop yield will be optimal. Julio, therefore, is asking Edpyme Alternativa, for the first time, for a 1000 new sol loan. Julio is a hard-working father who daily gives the best of himself to support his family; his greatest wish is to provide his children with a better education and to improve their quality of life. He is very well-liked in his community and his neighbors consider him trustworthy.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fertilize and irrigate his bayo (a type of pinto) bean crops.

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Irine is 26 years old, married to Mr Rotich, and they have two children aged seven and four. She was introduced to KADET by a friend who is an existing KADET client.

This is Irine's first loan which she will use to plough an extra part of her farm and plant more than in the previous season.

Her future plans are to invest in modern farming: by acquiring a greenhouse, she hopes to increase her productivity leading to more income which will enable her to educate her children and to be an independent woman.

loans.use: To plough the farm and buy seeds for planting

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and frozen food to sell.

loans.name: Benta Akumu

texts.en:
Benta Akumu O., a 40-year-old lady, is married to Peter Ogol and they have three children: Rodgers, aged 17; Frank, aged 15; and Verusa, aged 12. Benta and her family live in Onyalo town on the outskirts of Kisumu city.
