In 2007, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. As with her previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI which she has successfully repaid, this new loan of 30,000 PHP will be used to purchase the materials needed to expand the services provided. This will be the seventh loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the materials needed to provide more catering services

loans.name: Luz Eliana

texts.en:
Luz Eliana is 26 years old, lives with her spouse in Cuzco, and is currently three months pregnant with her first child. She is part of the “Unidos para el Triunfo” community bank, a name that translates to “United for Triumph."

Luz Eliana owns a currency changing business near the Plaza de Armas, a main tourist hub in the center of Cuzco. She opened this business eight years ago with the help of friends, and has been running the business ever since.

Luz Eliana is asking for a loan to help improve her business and to increase her business capital. Specifically, she wants to broaden the scope of her business by buying cameras and camera accessories to sell on the side in her money-exchange store.

She is appreciative of and thankful for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To purchase cameras and camera accessories to expand her business.

loans.name: Ledy Jane's Group

texts.en:
Ledy Jane S. is is 55 years old and from the village of Brgy. Uddiawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ledy Jane is married and has two adult children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Ledy Jane has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ledy Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Ledy Jane is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ernesto's Group

texts.en:
Ernesto D. F. Jr. is 52 years old and from the town of Sto. Domingo Echague. She is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is the Ernesto D. F. Jr. group.

Ernesto is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving local foods to customers in the local community. Ernesto has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ernesto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. As with her previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI which she has successfully repaid, this new loan of 9000 PHP will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This will be the third loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase food and drinks for the restaurant

loans.name: Lilia's Group

Lilia D. is 44 years old and from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lilia is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Lilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the first loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Claudio

texts.en:
Claudio is 44 years old and lives with his wife in Cuzco. Together they have four children, the oldest of whom is 22 and the youngest, 3. He says proudly that his 22-year-old is currently studying in a local university. Claudio makes his living as an electrical technician, and also sells spare parts and devices related to this job. 

Claudio is asking for a Kiva loan to help grow his small business by buying more spare parts to sell. He is appreciative of and thankful for the loan, and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: Spare parts

loans.name: Federose

texts.en:
Federose R. is 20 years old and is from the village of Brgy. Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married and has one infant child. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Federose has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Federose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the first loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Junica's Group

texts.en:
Junica B. is 25 years old and from the village of Brgy. Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Junica is married and has two infant children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling dried fish in the market. Junica has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Junica joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Junica is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Julia Ay

texts.en:
Julia is a 58-year-old married woman. She is part of the “Unidos para el Truinfo” community bank, a name that translates to “United for Triumph”. She and her husband have three adult children who all have families of their own and no longer live with their parents. Julia has supported herself and her family for years working in the candle business. She sells candles in a shop that she has owned and operated for over fifteen years. 

Julia is asking for a Kiva loan to buy materials to make candles so that she can increase her revenue. She is appreciative of and thankful for the loan, and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: Candles

loans.name: Marina Beatriz

texts.es:
La señora P.  se dedica a la venta de ropa de forma ambulante distribuyendo su mercadería a empleados de empresas con abonos diarios, semanales y mensuales  inicia su jornada de trabajo desde las 8:00Am a las 4:00pm.
 
 Este crédito lo solicito para  compra de mercadería apropiada en la temporada de Semana Santa.
 
Cabe mencionar que la Señora P.  esta agradecida  con ceprodel ya que ha logrado crecer en su negocio y dejar los prestamos con prestamistas.
texts.en:
La señora P. se dedica a la venta de ropa de forma ambulante distribuyendo su mercadería a empleados de empresas con abonos diarios, semanales y mensuales inicia su jornada de trabajo desde las 8:00Am a las 4:00pm. Este crédito lo solicito para compra de mercadería apropiada en la temporada de Semana Santa. Cabe mencionar que la Señora P. esta agradecida con ceprodel ya que ha logrado crecer en su negocio y dejar los prestamos con prestamistas.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de Pantalones, Short, Camisa, Vestidos, Trajes de Niño.

loans.name: Jose Felix

texts.en:
Jose Felix is 52 years old, single, and has no children. He lives with his mother in his childhood home. Jose Felix is part of the “Unidos para el Triunfo” community bank, a name that translates to “United for Triumph”. He makes his living in the candle business, and has been selling candles for over thirty years in a shop that he owns himself. He also makes the candles himself and buys the raw materials from a wholesaler in Lima, Peru’s capital city.

Jose Felix will use a Kiva loan to buy more raw materials for his candle business so that he can produce more and increase his revenue. He is appreciative of and thankful for the loan, and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To make and sell candles

loans.name: Los Girasoles Del Algodonal Group

texts.es:
El Grupo “LOS GIRASOLES DEL ALGODONAL” esta conformado por 9 socias todas amigas y vecinas del mismo lugar , la Sra. Apolonia es la tesorera del grupo,una mujer luchadora y trabajadora ella tiene un negocio D. lubricantes su negocio empezó por que se dio cuenta que por el lugar donD. vivía habían muchos paraderos D. carros los choferes siempre buscaban aceites ,lubricantes, filtros etc. Es así que deciD. poner ese tipo D. negocio,al principio fue algo dificil pero con el paso del tiempo logro hacerse D. clientela,ya tiene 4 años trabajando, su negocio ha crecido mucho permitiéndole con sus ganancias construir su casa y comprarse una camioneta que es indispensable como herramienta D. trabajo. para mas adelante a ella le gustaría extender su negocio y tener una sucursal, actualmente trabaja junto a su esposo ambos se ayudan y tratan D. sacar el negocio adelante, lo que hará con el dinero D. su préstamo es comprar mercadería para su tienda.

* la Sra. Apolonia es la 5ta D. la derecha esta vestida con polo rojo.
texts.en:
The group, “Los Girasoles Del Algodonal” is maD. up of nine members, all friends and neighbors from the same neighborhood. Apolonia is the treasurer. She is a hard working woman who runs a lubricants business. She began her business because she realized that there were many drivers in her neighborhood looking for oil, lubricants, filters, etc. Starting this sort of business was challenging, but with time she was able to develop steady customers. She has been working for four years and her business has grown to the point where her income has allowed her to have her home built and to buy a van, which is indispensable as a work tool. In the future she would like to be able to expand her business and open a second store. At the moment she works with her husband and they support one another and work to move the business forward. She will use the money from this loan to buy merchandise for her store. * Apolonia is the fifth person from the right in the photograph. She is wearing a red shirt.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol is part of the “Unidos para el Triunfo” community bank, which translates to “United for Triumph”. She is 40-years-old and lives in Cuzco with her spouse and their three children, ages fifteen, four, and two. Her oldest child studies in a local high school, and her youngest will soon be entering kindergarten. Marisol supports her family by selling ceviche, a common lunch dish made from raw fish and onions that have been “cooked” in lime juice. She says her business is currently going well, but that she would like to further increase her revenues from it.

Marisol will use her Kiva loan to improve this small business. She is appreciative of and thankful for the loan, and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy ceviche ingredients

loans.name: Celia Ysabel

texts.en:
Celia Ysabel is part of the “Unidos para el Triunfo” community bank, which translates to “United for Triumph”. She is 28-years-old and lives with her spouse and their two daughters, ages 16 and 5. The older one, Wyni, attends a local high school while 5-year-old Camila is enrolled in kindergarten. Celia Ysabel supports her family by buying and selling various types of potatoes. She buys them from a wholesaler in the jungle region of Puerto Maldonado, and sells them to various restaurants around the city of Cuzco. 

Celia Ysabel will use her Kiva loan as business capital for her potato enterprise. She has received Kiva loans in the past, and hopes to further improve her business with the current loan cycle. She is appreciative of and thankful for the loan, and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: For additional capital for her potato business

loans.name: Elphas

texts.en:
Elphas S. B. is 58 years old, married to Monicah Jeptum and they have four school going children. 

Elpahs has been in farming business for the last 15 years. He has been financed by KADET for two years now and he makes a minimum profit of Kshs 30,000 per harvest. He sells his produce to Kenya National cereals and Produce Board every year a government body that buys produce from farmers for storage. Before Elphas was introduced to Kadet by a relative he used to borrow from merry-go-round initiatives among his five friends.

He has borrowed money to buy fertilizers for maize farming, improve his poultry keeping and save S. money to buy second hand clothing for sale in December. He believes that the second hand clothing business will enable him pay for his son’s school fees as he is expected to join Secondary School next year. 

He intends to buy a second hand Lorry for transportation business especially transporting maize to cereals, when he doubles his planting acreage.

loans.use: To prepare his five acres of land for maize growing

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en: Dulamsuren U. is 41 years old and lives with her 16-year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter, Hongorzul, attends a local secondary school. Dulamsuren is a professional hairdresser. She started her business in 2001 after she moved to Ulaanbaatar. Over the years, she has expanded her business and has a loyal customer base because of her good service. With her business profit, she purchased her own plot of land with a house for her family. Dulamsuren has been planning to expand her business and renovate her equipment in the future. She is a proud mother and a very hardworking person who has been trying to provide a better life for herself and her daughter. She says, “My daughter will graduate soon from her high school, and I started saving some money for her university tuition fee. ” Dulamsuren is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~ 365 USD) loan to purchase necessary equipment and more hair dye products at wholesales prices for her business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for her hairdressing business

loans.name: Dulmaa

texts.en: Dulmaa T. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two teenage sons in Uvs province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent in a yard which belongs to her relatives. She and her husband are planning to purchase their own plot of land this year with their business profit. Currently, Dulmaa operates a shoe and saddle manufacturing business with her husband at their home. They have been operating their business since 1996, and it has steadily expanded. Her husband, Basan, makes the saddles and Dulmaa manufactures the shoes. Their business is well known to their customers. With their business profit, they purchased the ger which they are living in now. They are planning to create their own workplace after they purchase the plot of land for their family. Their product sales are high especially during the spring, summer and autumn. Dulmaa and her husband are both very hardworking people who are trying to provide better life for their family. Dulmaa says, 'I have been planning to save some money to pay university tuition fees for my two children who will become university students soon.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~  1465 USD) loan to purchase necessary materials to manufacture shoes and sell them to her many customers.

loans.use: To purchase materials for shoe manufacturing and sales

loans.name: Dorjdagva

texts.en: Dorjdagva N. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and  3 year old daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He has a very nice family with and they live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Dorjdagva operates a transportation business with his brother. He has been successfully operating his business since 2009 with his own truck. He earns between 300,000 – 400,000 tugrugs (~  250 USD) per trip. Dorjdagva has been planning to purchase a heavy duty truck which will help to increase his earning to 700,000 – 800,000 tugrugs (~ 550 USD).  Dorjdagva is an optimistic person who is focused on the future. He says, “My truck is main source of income for my business, and I would like to purchase heavier duty truck in order to increase my earnings. ” He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~  2195  USD) loan to contribute money to purchase a heavy duty truck for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a truck

loans.name: Huralgan

texts.en: Huralgan A. is 29 years old and lives with his wife in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. Huralgan operates a transportation business in his town.  He transports sand, gravel and stones with a truck he owns. In addition to this business, he also provides a garbage removal service to local households. He earns 30,000 tugrugs (~  21 USD) for transporting sand and gravel, and 25,000 tugrug (~ 18 USD) for loading garbage. He usually loads garbage three times per day. Huralgan has been operating his business since 1991, and has become an experienced driver.  Generally the demand for his business is high. Huralgan has been planning to purchase a car to operate a taxi service during the evening to earn extra money for his family. With his business profit, he has been saving money for the car. Huralgan says, “Loading garbage is not  easy work to do. Especially during the winter when the working conditions are very bad. However, I like to help people and my customers really appreciate my work and that makes me happy. ” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~  1465 USD) loan to contribute money to purchase a Korean car to operate as a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a car to operate as a taxi

loans.name: Revelita's Group

texts.en:
Revelita C. is 61 years old and is from the town of Capirpiriwan Cordon. She is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is the Revelita C. group.

Revelita is married and has eight adult children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal products such as glasses and watches in the local community. Revelita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Revelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Revelita is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Janarbek

texts.en:
Janarbek is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. His son is a primary school student and his daughter attends kindergarten.

Currently Janarbek operates a firewood transportation business with a truck he owns. Previously he operated an auto repair service for several years, and he purchased a truck which now he uses for his business.

He is an experienced driver and a very hardworking person. Janarbek says, “I would like to create my own auto repairing center in the future.”

He is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan to transport firewood from the countryside.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Melanie's Group

texts.en:
Melanie B. is 26 years old and from the town of B. San Agustin. She is the group leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is the Melanie B. group.

Melanie is married and has one infant child. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Melanie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Wilfredo's Group

texts.en:
Wilfredo G. is 51 years old and from the city of Rizal Santiago. He is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Wilfredo G.'s group.

Wilfredo is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing vehicle repairs to local community members. Wilfredo has been engaged in his business for over 26 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Wilfredo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. As with his previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which he has successfully repaid, this new loan of 10,000 PHP will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the ninth loan Wilfredo has taken out from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus is a hardworking married man who offers transport services to earn a living. He uses a motorbike to offer short distance transport service for goods and people. He has been in this business for eight years.

Cyrus belongs to a group of young entrepreneurs where he saves his money in Faulu Kenya. He appreciates that the organization has helped him improve his business, hence his better living standards.

He has requested a loan of 90000 KES to buy a motorbike. He hopes to buy more motorbikes in the future for better output. He sees himself venturing into taxi business in the next ten years.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a hardworking married lady with two children who go to school. She sells new and used clothes and shoes to earn a living. She also earns extra income from renting her residential houses.

Lilian was previously employed by the Kenya Airways company before she started this business. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been saving her money with her group named Diamond Women which enables her to access loans and her business has expanded.

Lilian has requested a loan of 80000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add stock of new clothes, used clothes, and shoes. She hopes to increase her turnover and make big investments in ten years time.

loans.use: To buy new clothes, used clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. V. is a married woman, 38 years old. She makes a living as a fish seller. Her husband, Say Thy (shown here) owns a car that he uses to transport  passengers or merchandise, which is a significant source of the family's income. The couple has three children, all of whom are in school or working. Recently her husband can’t earn as much as he did before because his car often breaks down. So she is applying for a loan to help her husband repair his old car. (Mrs. V. is not in the picture because she was busy when the photo was taken.)

loans.use: To repair an old car.

loans.name: Enos

texts.en: Enos is 35 years old and married with three children. He runs taxi business to earn a living. Previously he used bicycles but now he uses a motor cycle. He was able to make the change because of a loan of kes 40,000 that Faulu Kenya offered him. He saves his money with his group members named Fumulia in Faulu Kenya which enables him to access loans. He has requested a loan of kes 80,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy another motor cycle. In ten years time, he hopes to have several motor cycles for his business.

loans.use: To buy a motor cycle

loans.name: Eng's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Eng L. is 53 years old and the leader of nine-member loan group located in Prasath village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Eng L. cooks for her famiL. and takes care of her children. She has four children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a construction worker and the other two are students in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Hout Noun, is a construction worker who makes a small salary to support his famiL.. Mrs. Eng L. is requesting a loan to buy wood to build a chicken coop.

loans.use: To buy wood to build a chicken coop

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a 54 year old married lady with two children. She has been selling curtains, table cloths, and table mats for 13 years. She also earns more income from farming which she does together with her husband.

Ann belongs to a group named Emmanuel where she saves her money and shares business ideas. She has also been a member of Faulu Kenya which has helped her business grow.

Ann has requested a loan of 80000 KES to buy curtains and table cloths to sell. She hopes to expand her business into a wholesale one. She sees herself having many business outlets in the future.

loans.use: To buy curtains and table cloths to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Saing

texts.en:
Mrs. Saing N. was born in 1981. She is married and has two young children who are enrolled in school. To seek a daily income Saing N. is a garden keeper who works for a private company located in Phnom Pen. Her husband works with her in the same field and company.

Although they try to work hard, their income is frequently not adequate to support their family. Saing N. wants to invest in a new trade because she hopes she will get extra income.

Because Saing N. has no money yet, she is applying for a loan to buy a trailer that she will connect with an existing motorcycle that belongs to her husband, who operates a taxi service.

loans.use: To buy a trailer.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 27 years old and married with two children. He runs a hardware shop in Nairobi to earn a living. He also sells kerosene to earn extra income. He previously worked in the informal sector before he ventured into this business.

Since he joined Faulu Kenya he saves his money with his group named Hallelluyah, which enables him to access loans. He has learned to keep business records from the training that Faulu Kenya offered him together with his group members.

He has requested a loan of 80000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add stock of paint and hardware items for sale. He dreams of growing his business into a paint industry in the future.

loans.use: To purchase paint and other hardware items to sell.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 28 year old married lady with a son who attends school.  She has a timber yard where she sells poles and posts.  She was selling clothes before she ventured into this business.  

Joyce is a member of a group named Hope.  She has benefited from the group because the members meet on weekly basis to share business ideas and also save money.  She plans to increase her stock of poles and posts, and to start selling sand.  Therefore, she has requested a loan of KES 80,000 from Faulu Kenya.  She is determined to open up a hardware shop and dreams of building her family a house in the future.

loans.use: To increase her stock of poles and posts, and buy sand for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions, hair creams, and hair accessories to sell

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly Y., 56, sells breakfast foods and lives with her husband and seven children. She became a food seller in 2005, a skill she learned from a nearby neighbor. Two of her daughters are working at a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Meu Ny, is pictured here. He is a fisherman, and also has a pond where he raises fish to sell when they come to maturity. Meu Ny has sold all the grown fish from his pond and he is lacking capital to restock it. Therefore, Ly Y. has decided to seek a loan of $800 on her husband’s behalf from Kiva’s partner, HKL, to buy small fish for breeding.

loans.use: To buy small fish for breeding

loans.name: Thorn's Group

texts.en:
This group loan from Preak Raing village in Kandal province consists of 17 members. Mrs. Thorn V. was selected by the other members as the village bank president. The members will use the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs.Thorn V. is 48 years old.  Her husband is a vice village chief, for which he receives a small salary to support his family.  They have four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a labourer, and the other two are students who also support their mother’s business.  Mrs. Thorn V. is a grocery seller who owns a general store. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, and has thus decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries and expand her business activities.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks and bottle water to sell.

loans.name: San

texts.en: Mrs. San S., 31, is a married woman living in Phnom Penh. She is garment worker and is a good homemaker who currently stays at home to care for her children and do housework. She has three teenagers who are in school. She sometimes depends on her husband, who works as a fisherman in and around the river, for income. Recently some of his fishing tools were ruined, forcing him to suspend his activity, and the family’s income has been affected. To help solve the matter, San S. is asking for a loan to repair the broken tools and to buy more tools, such as a boat, net, and trap, to improve the fishing business. Note: the man shown in the photo is Mrs. San S.'s husband.

loans.use: Fishing tool repair and purchase

loans.name: Kem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Kem K. is 60 years old, and has a child who is a student. She has been selected by the other 4 members of her group, located in Svay Prey village in Kandal province, as its leader. The members will use their portions of the loan to purchase equipment, supplies and other items for different purposes. 

Mrs. Kem K. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Hean Hin, is a bike repairman who earns a small income to help support his family. Mrs. Kem K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase bike supplies to support her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase bike supplies
